Found this article after I Googled Frank Gould: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9506E3D91539E13AB... That's the first Mrs. Gould and the girls names are Helen & Dorothy.

Mrs. Frank Gould was the former Helen Margaret Kelly, daughter of Edward Kelly and granddaughter of banker Eugene Kelly. She was 18 years old when she married Frank Gould, youngest son of financier Jay Gould, on December 2nd, 1901. The wedding was reported in the New York Times the following day. They divorced in 1908, and the terms of the settlement were described in this New York Times article from May 11, 1909. Though Frank Gould was granted custody of his daughters for the greater part of each year, young Helen and Dorothy ended up spending most of that time with their aunt, Helen Gould, who became Mrs. Finley J. Shepard in 1913 (Times article.) The former Mrs. Frank Gould married twice more (that I can find), in 1910, to Ralph Thomas (d.1914), and in 1917 to Prince Houreddin (or Noureddin) Vlora of Albania, from whom she was divorced in 1922 (brief Times Article.) Daughters Helen and Dorothy both went on to marry Swiss Barons, and then divorce them according to a brief item in Time Magazine on February 18th, 1935. I've been unable to find what became of Helen after her divorce, but Dorothy was married again, to Basil Frederick Boothby, which got her cited in Burke's Peerage. She died in 1990.
There is another photo of the kids here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3084403295/
I added her to Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Margaret_Kelly

Dorothy Gould Burns (1904-1969) died in 1969. Her second, and last husband was Archibald Burns, a Mexican national of Scottish parents. I don't know where the incorrect information from "The Peerage" came from, but it is incorrect. I will add a short biography of her to Wikipedia. Source: ftp.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/532/532.F2d.809.75-6062....

Correction: Helen & Dorothy were not twins.  Helen was born  Sept 19, 1902 on the yacht Helenita at anchor in Oyster Bay, Long Island, NY.  Dorothy was born at home 834 Fifth Ave, NYC.  Source: The News-Democrat, Oct 9, 1906 (free access via Google News Archive).

Also, the spelling of her maiden name varies -- some news accounts use Kelly others Kelley.  An account of her grandfather's great accomplishments uses both spellings in the same article.  See (free via Google News Archive)  Lewiston Evening Journal, Dec 19, 1894 – Death of Eugene Kelley, a well known Irish-American and His Busy and Worthy Life.

See notes on Butler under:

The machine says "Made by M Butler, Patents pending." A Charles H. Butler (from California) had several patents for street cleaning equipment, e,g,. www.google.com/patents?id=aSxIAAAAEBAJ and www.google.com/patents?id=ryBpAAAAEBAJ The drawings looks similar although not identical. Patent number: 808006 Filing date: Oct 20, 1904 Issue date: Dec 1905 Patent number: 880124 Filing date: Oct 20, 1904 Issue date: Feb 1908 Patent number: 909865 Filing date: Dec 16, 1905 Issue date: Jan 19, 1909 Patent number: 1134586 Filing date: Aug 25, 1914 Issue date: Apr 6, 1915 Patent number: 1610119 Filing date: Dec 15, 1924 Issue date: Dec 1926

I presume that the Magnus Butler who shows up in a couple of the pictures in this group was the M. Butler who made the Butler Automatic Street Cleaner. And I suspect that these photos were most likely taken in November, 1914, when New York's Department of Street Cleaning hosted a week-long Exhibition of Street Cleaning which, among other things, allowed manufacturers to demonstrate their street cleaning equipment.

Left hand side building in back ground has sign "The Baker & Taylor " which is probably The Baker & Taylor Co. publishing firm. Maybe this is The Century building at 33 to 37 East Seventeenth Street, which The Baker & Taylor Co purchased in 1901. (ref. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0CE5DB143FE433A... )

Interesting vehicle! Solid rubber tires, extra spokes on both sets of wheels (16 front; 18 rear), chain drive, hand-operated horn, fuel tank under driver's seat, vertical steering column, right-hand drive, massive riveted steel frame.

I don't think Magnus Butler's machine is related to the pneumatic street sweepers in the Charles Butler patents. The Magnus Butler machine appears to be a mechanized dump wagon. There's no visible cleaning apparatus (rotary brush, conveyors, belts, etc.), just a tilting hopper with a gate at the rear and access doors on the sides. The streets of NYC were apparently still being cleaned by men with pushbrooms and hand carts. Machines were found to be less effective and more expensive than manual laborers. The Magnus Butler motorized wagon was probably designed as a collection vehicle to carry away the rubbish from the hand carts and dump it elsewhere. The raised letters on the rear wheel casting, visible in another photo, suggest the machine may have been made in Mass. (it could just indicate the maker of the wheel hubs, but the hubs are unusual, so they could have been custom-made ) See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2497227956/ For more about street cleaning, download MODERN METHODS OF STREET CLEANING by GEORGE A. SOPER, PH.D. (1909) from the Internet Archive www.archive.org/details/texts

There are lots of patents for mechanized dump wagons from the 1910s. Here are a few: www.google.com/patents/about?id=z2FLAAAAEBAJ www.google.com/patents/about?id=2TZKAAAAEBAJ www.google.com/patents/about?id=RiRdAAAAEBAJ www.google.com/patents/about?id=1pFWAAAAEBAJ Bingo! www.google.com/patents/about?id=cUJIAAAAEBAJ This one was filed in Lawrence, Massachusetts, by Paul Hannagan. The words "Lawrence Mass." can be read on the rear wheel hub of Butler's machine. Hannagan filed six patents between 1906 and 1916, all relating to street maintenance. Conclusion: Magnus Butler was the builder of this vehicle (the painted lettering reads "Made by M. Butler"), while Paul Hannagan was the inventor/designer, with "patents pending" at the time this photo was taken. Patent number: 1176677 Filing date: May 29, 1912 Issue date: Mar 21, 1916 The "Auto, Street Cleaner" doesn't mean "automotic street cleaner." More likely, it means "automobile, street cleaner."

Everyone,

Thanks for all the industrious research on this street cleaner and its creators. We can now add a bit more detail to the caption when we update.

According to a Wikipedia article at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commissioner_of_Baseball : "The National Commission was the ruling body of professional baseball starting with the National Agreement of 1903, which made peace between the National League and the American League (see History of baseball in the United States). It consisted of three members: the two League presidents and a Commission chairman, whose primary responsibilities were to preside at meetings and to mediate disputes." The Commission's only chairman was August Herrmann, who resigned after the 1919 scandal: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E02E6DA153EE433A...

Prince Henry (with the plumed hat) was the prince consort of Queen Wilhelmina, Queen of the Netherlands from 1890 until 1948, when she abdicated in favor of her daughter. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelmina_of_the_Netherlands He was Duke Heinrich Wladimir Albrecht Ernst of Mecklenburg-Schwerin (April 19, 1876 – July 3, 1934). They were married in 1901. This looks like Versailles and is probably from the same event as hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.13132, a Bain picture not loaded to Flickr (yet). ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/22826?view=synopsis suggests June 1912 might have been the date, because the film has a segment from that date, 'Fallieres and Queen Wilhelmina seen entering a state coach together, '. Fallieres was President of France.

Prince Henry is actually short for Prince Hendrik of Mecklenburg-Schwerin. He was a duke and was not made Prince of the Netherlands until February 6, 1901. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hendrik_of_Mecklenburg-Schwerin He and Queen Wilhelmina had a daughter, the heir to the throne, Princess Julia, who became Queen in 1948.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 15. -- Mulai Hafid, ex-Sultan of Morocco, arrived here this morning on board the steamship Macedonia. His progress to his hotel was watched by a dense throng of people, but there was no cheering.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- Mulai Hafid, the ex-Sultan of Morocco, is the hero of the moment here. Thanks to all for their comments.  While the New York Times is often a fairly reliable source for the spelling of a name, the December 15, 1912 article mentioned in several comments includes misspellings. It is identified as 'Special to the New York Times', and so may have been provided by a visiting correspondent - and not well fact-checked. This photograph shows Mrs. Malcolm Strauss and her prize-winning French Bulldog Beaux Athos.   Bain provides the identities as: Mrs. Malcolm Strauss and Beaux Attos, and this Dec 1912 column offers Mrs. Martin Straus and Beau Athos, where both names are incorrect.

Numerous other articles in the New York Times reporting results of dog shows in great detail confirm both the name of the owner - and her husband - and her dog.  A good authority for the dog's name in particular is the American Kennel Stud Book of 1913, published by the National American Kennel Club.  Here he is noted as: Beaux Athos. 

We will amend the record to include the correct name for the bulldog.

This guy had an interesting life. Maurice Bennett "Lefty" Flynn (born Greenwich, Connecticut on May 26, 1892) was a star athlete at Yale in the early 1910s. His college football career was cut short in 1913 when he was barred from the school following his marriage to a chorus girl, Irene Leary. (New York Times article.) The couple separated after 11 days, and their divorce became final the next year (New York Times article.) In 1916 he married a second time, to Blanche Shove Palmer, with whom he had two children. The world had not heard the last of Lefty, though. By 1919, he had begun a career in movies which would last until 1927 (IMDb filmography page.) His Hollywood career included another brief marriage, to silent star Viola Dana. Their movie careers ended with the silent era, and they were divorced in 1929. By the 1930s, Lefty was living in Tryon, North Carolina and was married to the former Nora Langhorne Phipps, youngest sister of Nancy, Viscountess Astor, and of Irene Gibson, said to have been one of the models for the Gibson Girl, created by her husband, illustrator Charles Dana Gibson. The Flynns were acquainted with F. Scott Fitzgerald, and it was with them that his daughter Scottie stayed when Fitzgerald went to Tryon for his health in 1935. Zelda Fitzgerald's biographer, Nancy Cline, claims that Scott Fitzgerald had an affair with Nora Flynn. I've been unable to find whether or not Lefty and Nora remained married until Nora's death in 1955 (her obituary in the Hickory Daily Record refers to her as Mrs. Nora Langhorne Flynn), but Lefty married once again, to Lesley Bogert, before his own death on March 6, 1959, in Camden, South Carolina.
I started a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Bennett_Flynn

Otis Love Guernsey was a Yale football player (a "kicking fullback," in the New York Times) and "squash tennis" player.  His father was Nathaniel T. Guernsey, a prominent corporate lawyer (also a Yalie).  Otis married Margaret C. Henderson, and their son Otis Love Guernsey Jr. (1918-2001, also a Yalie) was  a drama critic and longtime editor of the "Best Plays" series (Broadway plays, not football plays).

Polish-American boxer Stanley Ketchel (birth name Stanislaus Kiecal) was born in Grand Rapids Michigan, September 14, 1886. In his brief professional boxing career he won the middleweight championship twice, and held that title at the time he was murdered, on October 15, 1910. A biography of Ketchel can be found at: www.boxrec.com/media/index.php/Stanley_Ketchel

Seems like William Jennings Bryan or Woodrow Wilson should be there but I don't see them.

The principal task of the National Committee's delegates was to write a party platform for the national convention, every four years. During the year 1912, the National Democratic Party Chairmen were Norman E. Mack (outgoing) and William F. McCombs (incoming), both of whom happened to be from New York State. Perhaps one or the other of them is in this photograph.

Although the 1912 Democratic Convention had been held in Baltimore, the Democrats' Executive Committee subsequently established the National Headquarters in a suite of ten rooms on the fifth floor of the Fifth Avenue Building in New York City, with frontage on 23rd Street. This photo probably shows us one of those palatial paneled rooms. New York Times story (with a photo of Mr. McCombs and other executives gathered around a table), July 30, 1912: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E02EFDD1630E2... [Others in the NYT photo include A. Mitchell Palmer, who became Wilson's Attorney General, Josephus Daniels, who became Secretary of the Navy, and William McAdoo, who became Treasury Secretary and later Wilson's son-in-law. The blind Senator Thomas Pryor Gore of Oklahoma is there, too: he was Vice President Al Gore's great-grandfather.]

From the NYT, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9907EFD7123CE633A... FORTY NATIONS IN COMMERCE CONGRESS; Session Opens in Boston on Oct. 24, After Which Delegates Will Tour the Country. September 16, 1912, Monday Representatives of forty nations, some of whom will arrive at this port to-morrow, and the others during the week, will attend the fifth International Congress of Chambers of Commerce and Industrial Associations in Boston Oct. 24 to 26, inclusive, which will be the most important meeting of its kind in the history of the commercial world. ... Among the delegates arriving tomorrow will be three who played a leading part on the Chinese revolution. They are Dr. Chen Chin-tao, a Yale graduate who served as Minister of Finance at Nanking; Dr C. C. Wang, also of Yale and the University of Illinois, who recently was appointed Director of the Mukden Railway, and Dr, Fu Liang.

It looks like there are six or seven rows of SEATS in front of the "Green Monster", which is hard to understand. They would have been ridiculously close to the action, dangerously so -- the wall is 304 feet from the plate. I also don't see the famous "Duffy's Cliff" rising up in front of it. I'm guessing that they took these seats out almost immediately, and the ground under them slopes up, and was left that way (until 1934). Fascinating picture. I've blogged it here: fnarf.blogspot.com/2008/04/boston-ball-grounds-1912-panor...
Amazing picture because of how old Fenway Park is and to think it still stands in the same place it did in 1912.

It was actually 324 feet in 1912, Yawkey added seats and pushed home plate out during the 1934 rebuild. The bleachers were temporarily added to Duffy's Cliff for the World Series. In some old pictures you can see fans sitting back on right and center field in a roped off area when they used to jam 'em in. Here is some good info on the history of the park: www.andrewclem.com/Baseball/FenwayPark.html

Champ Clark was Wilson's rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1912.  Clark received the majority of the votes on the early ballots at the Democratic convention, but did not achieve the 2/3 that he needed to win.  Ultimately Clark faded and Wilson prevailed, but Clark was bitter over his defeat.

My grandfather worked for  Harriet Pratt's father, Herbert L. Pratt, at Pine Tree Point, his retreat in the Adirondacks of New York State. In 1923, Harriet married Lawrence Van Ingen. In 1938, she married Donald Bush.   

When my grandfather retired in 1960, my father, Charles Kirche, took over the Pine Tree Point caretakers' job.  While going to college, I earned spending money by working at that camp, and I still remember "Mrs. Bush" as a great and gracious lady.

Still today, I often drive by my parent's old house across the road from the Pine Tree Point camp and recall the happy days of my youth working for the Pratt family.

Submitted by Donald Kirche

Found his obit in NY Times dated October 25, 1937. Lafayette Blanchard Gleason was Secretary of the Republican State Committee for 31 years, starting in 1906, and he was also General Secretary of seven Republican National Conventions. He passed away at age 74, he was born May 30, 1863. He was described as a political encyclopedia. He was also a lawyer who specialized in inheritance tax litigation. At his death he was a widower, his wife was Mrs. Frances Rich (Mc)Entee when he married her at Bridgeport, Conn in 1908, died in 1936. He had one son Gor(don?), by an earlier marriage.

Quoting from a website:

John P. Jaeckel (April 22, 1865 Syracuse, Onondaga County, New York - June 16, 1941 Auburn, Cayuga County, New York) was an American politician.


Life
His was born of German parents at Syracuse, N.Y., but the family removed soon to Auburn, N.Y. He worked as a money-order clerk at the Auburn post-office, and later as a confidential clerk and bookkeeper for a coal dealer.

As a Republican, he was Auburn City Treasurer from 1895 to 1898. He was New York State Treasurer from 1899 to 1902, elected in 1898 and 1900.

On October 29, 1901, he was the foreman of the witnesses to the execution of Leon Czolgosz [the assassin of President William McKinley] at Auburn State Prison.

He was President of the State Prison Commission, and a member of the Board of Parole which in 1904 denied number racketeer Albert J. Adams's application for parole.

In 1920, he was chosen the first Auburn City Manager.

Edit: See edits below for correct identifications. Frankie "Young Britt" Pacheco was a boxer in the 1910s (here and here.). He was arrested for manslaughter on January 1st, 1919, in Boston, following the death in the ring the previous night of his opponent, a boxer who went by the name of Terry McGovern (New York Times article.) I haven't been able to find out what happened after that. I haven't been able to identify the Williams in the photo. EDIT: It turns out that there were two boxers fighting under the name Young Britt during the 1910s. The Frankie "Young Britt" Pacheco (born 1895) in my earlier comment apparently used the name Frankie Britt for most of his career. Here's his BoxRec bout list under that name. As can be seen, his career continued after the unfortunate death of Terry McGovern. The other Young Britt was a bantamweight named Henry Treffinger, born in 1890, whose career lasted from 1906 until 1916 (BoxRec bout list.) The Williams in the photo might be Kid Williams (aka John Gutenko), a bantamweight who was active in the ring from 1910-1929, but I can't find any evidence that he ever fought either of the Young Britts. Additional Edit: See comments on this photo of the same boxers for more about their correct identities (Kid Williams, aka John Gutenko, and Young Britt, aka Henry Treffinger.) This is not Frankie "Young Britt" Pacheco.

From: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940CE1D9133CE633A... 'November 12, 1912, Tuesday The jury which is to try the gunmen -- "Gyp the Blood" Horowitz, "Lefty Louie" Rosenberg, "Whitney" Lewis, and "Dago Frank" Cirofici -- in Justice Goff's Extraordinary Term of the Supreme Court was completed at exactly 7:10 o'clock yesterday evening after a court session lasting with an hour's recess from 10:30 o'clock in the morning.' According to: www.davidpietrusza.com/Becker-Rosenthal-Case.html 'Arnold Rothstein and Herman “Beansy” Rosenthal were protégés of Lower East Side Tammany Hall boss Big Tim Sullivan. He understated Rothstein's talents; he tragically overestimated Rosenthal. In 1912 Rosenthal was running a gambling house at 104 W. 45th Street with Lt. Charles Becker (1873-1915), head of the NYPD vice squad—and overlord of a widespread system of Police shakedowns. When the two fell out, Becker put Rosenthal out of business. Rosenthal—despite Rothstein's warnings—threatened to blow the lid off "The System," finally taking his story to Herbert Bayard Swope (best man at Rothstein's wedding) at the New York World. In July 1912 the World printed Rosenthal's story. An enraged Becker ordered Rosenthal's death, and a quartet of killers—Jacob Seidenshner (aka Whitet Lewis), Frank "Dago Frank" Cirofici, Louis "Lefty Louie" Rosenberg and Harry "Gyp the Blood" Horowitz—rubbed out Rosenthal as he exited Big Tim Sullivan's Metropole Hotel at 142 West 43rd Street, just off Times Square, on the evening of July 16, 1912. The four gunmen were found guilty of Rosenthal's murder on November 19, 1912.' Becker was tried separately [see http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2349132043/] and convicted. The first conviction (October 1912) was overturned but he was tried again a couple of years later. All five were executed. See also: www.crimemagazine.com/killercop.htm sixforfive.blogspot.com/2007/02/harry-horowitz-aka-gyp-bl... and books.google.com/books?id=29R4MyhnVb4C&pg=PT55&lp...

Woodrow Wilson was the twenty-eighth President of the United States.  He was one of the leading intellectuals during the progressive era.  His second term was in the heart of World War I.  His "idealist" and "realist" positions on foreign policy made him, according to some scholars, as one of the greatest presidents yet.  In this photo, he appears to be very stern and in front of a governmental building.

Probably taken in September 1912. See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05E0D6123CE633A... EDISON TRAIN A SUCCESS.; Three-Car Storage Battery Demonstration to be Given To-morrow. Special to The New York Times. September 24, 1912, Tuesday WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Successful tests of a three-car train of Edison storage battery cars were made last week on the Watchung branch of the Erie Railroad, between West Orange and Forest Hill. They have encouraged Mr. Edison to such a degree that he has arranged for a public demonstration on Wednesday in trip from the Pennsylvania Railroad Station, New York, to Long Beach.

Thanks swanq.  That reads like a significant day in rail history.

I wonder where Edison got the rail cars?

The story says he built them at his battery factory but it seems likely he bought the cars and equipped them with his batteries. They were intended for United Railways of Cuba. I wonder if they're still in use, or sitting in a railroad museum somewhere in Cuba?

The Edison cell was one of Edison's most profitable inventions. It has several advantages over other kinds of rechargeable cells, the main one being that it lasts forever and is immune to physical and electrical abuse. In comparison, lithium cells only last three years no matter how much you use them, and just a few deep discharges or overcharges can kill a NiMH cell.

Charles (1882-1912) and Gabriel (1880-1973) Voisin were pioneers of aviation. Their company, Voisin Freres, was the Europe's first commercial airplane factory. Charles died in an automobile accident in 1912. Gabriel continued to manufacture aircraft until, following World War I, he turned to the production of luxury automobiles, citing as a reason his distress at the way aircraft had been used for violence during the war. He continued to make automobiles under the marque Avions Voisin into the 1950s. Information about the Voisin brothers pioneering work in aviation can be found online at this link, along with numerous images.

Paul Drennan Cravath (1861-1940) was a prominent New  York attorney and a power in the Republican party for several decades. The son of militant abolitionists (his father, Erastus Cravath, was the founding president of Fisk University), Cravath graduated from Oberlin in 1882 and from Columbia College law school in 1886. He married Agnes Huntington, a former opera singer, in 1892. His law firm, now   Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP, remains one of the most succesful in the world. 

Vera Agnes Huntington Cravath (b.1896), who appears with him in this photo,  was his daughter. The occasion was probably a horse race or horse show. Both Cravath and his daughter, an avid horsewoman,  exhibited show horses during the period when this photo was taken. Vera Cravath married at least twice: to Lt. James S. Larkin, about 1917, and to William Francis Gibbs in 1927.

Could these be the grandchildren of Mrs. Edith Cooper Bryce, wife of Lloyd S. Bryce, former United States Minister to the Netherlands? Upon her death on April 29, 1916, she left a life interest in more than a million dollars to her husband. When he died on April 2, 1917, it reverted to the residuary estate to be distributed among her children and grandchildren. A New York Times article of April 3, 1918, names daughter Edith C. Cram and grandchildren Henry G. Cram, Edith Bryce Cram, and John Cram, among other beneficiaries. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A06EFD91E3FE4... The 1920 U.S. census for New York shows the Cram family living on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan: John S. Cram, a lawyer aged 62, his wife Edith C., age 38, their children Harry S., age 12, Edith B., age 11, and John S., age 9, along with a butler, a nurse, a cook, a governess, a housekeeper, a waitress, and a maid. All of the family members were born in New York with the exception of Edith C., who was born in Washington. Given their ages in 1920, it is likely that the photograph above was taken several years later than 1910, as Harry would have been two years old and Edith only one year old in 1910. My guess would be perhaps 1914, at ages six and five.
My goodness, even today that's a lot of  money to inherit.

This remarkable action shot obviously was not a summertime photo, but on another occasion, in August, 1913, Emil Seelig's horses won several ribbons in harness racing at a three-day competition at Hollywood Park race track, Monmouth County, Long Branch, New Jersey. His "Emil Seelig Kaffee" was an international brand of coffee, with a high chicory content. Here is the story from the New York Times, August 3, 1913: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9C0DE...

Thanks Wystan, for the links.  Wish we knew more about where this photograph was taken.  At the very least we will add the missing word "horses" to the title, but hold off making major changes until we learn more.

NYT of November 24, 1912, has a report of the running of New York City's four-in-hand race of that year, which paired an Emil Seelig coach against one driven by G. P. Taylor. The race was a revival of an earlier annual event; there had been no coach race in 1911. It was delayed twice by accidents on the course, which were caused by horses slipping on asphalt pavement. 

The 1912 race began at the Arrowhead Inn (built in 1908, torn down in 1923) in Washington Heights [at 178th St. (now the George Washington Bridge road, or I-95) and Haven Ave.], and ended at Madison Square Garden, where a throng of spectators waited patiently for the arrival of each coach-and-four. 

Presumaby this photograph shows the beginning of the 1913 race, this time with Seelig and Taylor joining forces against a competitor identified as "Judge Moore." Alas, veterinarians disqualified one of the Judge's horses for lameness, and Taylor won by default. On the other hand, the 1913 NYT story says Taylor drove a yellow coach. Does the coach in the photo look yellow? The 1913 story doesn't say where the race began.
The driver is E. Fownes.  The other guy in the front is Paul A. Sorg.  Check other Library of Congress photos and you'll see this matches up with a close up shot of Fownes & Sorg.

 I grew up in a house that the Sorgs built in Middletown Ohio, begun in the year the elder Sorg, tycoon Paul John Sorg, died.  The son, Paul Arthur Sorg, was 26 in 1904 when the house was completed but his bride, Grayce, a Philadelphia society girl, refused to live in Ohio, even in the elegant mansion on the hill.  So Sorg used the same plans and built the house, this time with Tudor details,  in Chataqua, NY, a much more fashionable place, and close to Gragce's parents' house.  Paul Arthur Sorg was a flamboyant character and very fond of racing four-in-hands.

Other Bain/LOC photos of visiting British Suffragette leader Emmeline Pankhurst, addressing (or attempting to address) a rowdy, noisy crowd of young males beside the Subtreasury Building on Wall Street, New York City, on November 27, 1911:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163792086/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163793234/]

In the vehicle with Mrs. Pankhurst were Hariot Stanton Blatch, U. S. Suffragist leader, and the venerable Dr. Anna Howard Shaw.

Mrs. Pankhurst made a return visit to America in October, 1913. On that occasion, foolish U. S. immigration officials decided to bar entry to her, holding her at Ellis Island for deportation. This created a cause celebre, and required the personal intervention of U. S. President Woodrow Wilson to admit her for an already-scheduled lecture tour. The publicity helped suffragist fundraising enormously.

Nataley Shrum. Why not visit any of the help groups or read the Flickr page on Wikipedia? Flickr was a lot better ten years ago. It's way too big now and things change with no respect for serious photographers on here. Flickr used to be a great place to discuss photography, but has now morphed into a source of instant eye candy for younger people who tend to scroll through thousands of images per minute using their smart phones. It used to be if a person got 100 views in a day on an image, that was pretty good. Now, people get a million views for some stupid photograph. All you have to do is put your photo in 200 groups and list 200 tags even if they have nothing to do with your photo. Explore became a joke years ago, but is even more of a joke now. Oh, and, btw, your photos will be stolen by some goofball who will put them on her Pinterest board and you won't be given any credit for having taken it. Yeah, it's why I hate Flickr. I have had over 700 photos that I know of stolen from Flickr. You can check your photos by dropping your image into the Google camera or by using Tineye. The "gunmen" referred to (though hard to clearly identify in this photo) are 4 individuals with colorful nicknames -- "Gyp the Blood" Horowitz, "Lefty Louie" Rosenberg, "Whitey" Lewis, and "Dago Frank" Cirofici -- who were convicted of killing Herman Rosenthal, proprietor of an alleged gambling house in New York City.  

Apparently just days before his murder earlier in July, Rosenthal, according to period accounts, was in the process of contacting the city's District Attorney, hinting at police corruption and threatening to divulge the secrets of the gambling community.

For newspaper stories directly related to this photo, refer to the following:

1) GUNMEN HEAR TO-DAY THE DEATH SENTENCE; Sheriff Will Take Them to Sing Sing at Once, Guarding Against Attack. INFORMERS HAVE VANISHED Jack Rose Can Be a Sicilian Marquis -- Title Offered for Part of Profits from His Book.
New York Times. New York, N.Y.: Nov 26, 1912. p. 24 

& 2) GUNMEN NEAR BECKER IN THE DEATH HOUSE; Four Sentenced to Die in Week Beginning Jan. 6, and Hurried Off to Sing Sing. CROWDS HINDER THE SHERIFF Wives of Two Gunmen Go with Them to Prison and Receive Their Valuables.
New York Times. New York, N.Y.: Nov 27, 1912. p. 9

For details regarding Herman Rosenthal's murder, see

GAMBLER WHO DEFIED POLICE IS SHOT DEAD. New York Times. New York, N.Y.: Jul 16, 1912. p. 1

You'll find that period newspaper accounts are great tools for finding fascinating details of as-it-happened events, often in much more (and gruesome) detail.

Pittsburgh is spelled here minus the final (and silent) "h," reflecting usage introduced by President Theodore Roosevelt's American spelling reforms. After several years, Pittsburgh officially decided to resume use of the "h".

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Pickering's, a huge furniture emporium in downtown Pittsburgh whose advertising banners appear on two of the buildings in this photo, called itself the "largest credit furniture and carpet house in the world." A contemporary publication added this information:

      "Mention 'Pickering's' anywhere within a several-hundred-mile radius of Pittsburgh and hear how quickly some one answers, 'Your credit's good' or 'Nuf ced!'

      "The reason for the unprecedented growth of the business is as well known as Pickering's popular trade-mark expressions: fair dealing, nothing else. That means the best possible goods at the lowest prices consistent with a living profit; a hearty willingness to extend the people credit; an honest, wholesome way of treating customers after the goods have been delivered.

      "At Tenth Street and Penn Avenue you will find furniture, carpets, rugs, draperies, gas and coal ranges, heaters, dinner-ware, toilet-ware, framed pictures, cut glass, and bric-a-brac."

Former President Theodore Roosevelt was being treated in the hospital in Chicago after being shot in Milwaukee by John Schrank (of New York City) in a botched assassination attempt, October 1912. Jane Addams (September 6, 1860 – May 21, 1935) was the first American woman to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. In a long, complex career, she was a pioneer settlement worker and founder of Hull House in Chicago, public philosopher (the first American woman in that role), sociologist, author, and leader in woman suffrage and world peace. She was the most prominent woman of the Progressive Era and helped turn the nation to issues of concern to mothers, such as the needs of children, public health and world peace. She emphasized that women have a special responsibility to clean up their communities and make them better places to live, arguing they needed the vote to be effective. Addams became a role model for middle-class women who volunteered to uplift their communities. She is increasingly being recognized as a member of the American pragmatist school of philosophy. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Addams

Elise Ladew of Glen Cove, L.I. married William R. Grace in 1914. They had three daughters. Her husband's father, also William R Grace served two terms as the Mayor of New York. Elise's husband William studied "for a time" at Columbia, joined the family company but soon left for Ingersoll Drill company, which his father also controlled. His brother, Joseph P. Grace became chairman of the W.R. Grace Company. The husband died in 1943 (obit dated April 1, 1943) at age 64.

Greek immigrant men on ship "Martha Washington," sailing from Port of New York to return to Greece to fight in First Balkan War, October, 1912.

USS Martha Washington, a 12,700-ton troop transport, was originally the Austrian passenger steamer Martha Washington. Launched at Port Glasgow, Scotland in 1908, she was interned at Hoboken, New Jersey, after World War I began in August 1914. When the United States entered the conflict in April 1917, she was taken over by the Army Quartermaster Corps. The Navy acquired the ship in November 1917 and placed her in commission in January 1918. Martha Washington made her first transport voyage to France in February and during the remainder of the First World War crossed the Atlantic seven more times, bringing more than 24,000 personnel to Europe. With the Armistice in November, Martha Washington reversed the pattern, making seven trips over the next year to return nearly 20,000 passengers to America. In August 1919, she was sent into the Mediterranean and Black Seas to carry a U.S. mission to Turkey and Russia. During this three-month voyage, she also carried refugees from Batum, Russia, to Constantinople, Turkey. Martha Washington decommissioned in November 1919, shortly after her return to the U.S. from Turkey, and was sold back to her Austrian former owners in November 1922. Source: www.history.navy.mil/photos/sh-usn/usnsh-m/id3019.htm

Glenn Curtiss's first flying boat, the 1912 Flying Fish, is depicted in this Bain photo. Note the squarish tail. The rounded tail of the flying boat in the photo above was a feature of Curtiss's second such craft, the America, built in 1914. Photos of the America and a modern reproduction of it are on this page at the Glenn Curtiss Museum website. Curtiss tested his flying boats near Hammondsport, on Lake Keuka in the Finger Lakes district of upstate New York. The America was tested on July 12, 1914, and was the subject of this New York Times article the following day. Note that the article cites the speed of the craft as 60 mph, matching the speed cited in the caption on this Bain photo. A 1912 Times report on the testing of the Flying Fish gives the top speed of that craft as 54 mph. The photo above almost certainly depicts the America, probably on July 12, 1914.

What year do you think this picture is taken? Here are some clues from the history of these folks: On the right: Greek Prince Christopher (1888-1940). His father was originally a Danish prince (does Christopher look Danish?). Through an unusual twist of history, his Danish father (1845-1913) became King George I of Greece in 1863 when he was only 17. King George had a long rule of 50 years and he was married for 46 years to Olga Konstantinovna (1851-1926) of Russia, they married in 1867. (That seems to be her, in the middle of the photo). They had 8 children, including Christopher who was the youngest. King George was assassinated in 1913 at age 68 (during the first Balkan war). Christopher was then age 25. Queen Olga, age 62, became a dowager at this point, another word for a widow. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_I_of_Greece George was succeeded by his and Olga's oldest son who became King Constantine (1868-1923), who was Christopher's brother. Constantine was educated at Heidelberg University in Germany, trained in the Prussian army, and married to a nice Prussian girl, Princess Sophie of Prussia (1870-1932). On her mother's side Sophie's grandparents were Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of England. Her grandfather on her father's side was German emperor and her father was German emperor too and so was her brother, Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany. Constantine was king of Greece from 1913-1917. During World War I Greece was neutral but eventually sided with the Allies. Constantine was was forced to abdicate and leave Greece due to his pro-German affiliations and sympathies. He abdicated in favor of his second son (and Olga's grandson) Alexander who did not last long as king. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constantine_I_of_Greece

Alexander (1893-1920) was king from 1917 to 1920. In 1919 King Alexander scandalously married a commoner, Aspasia Manos, (1896-1972) who is standing on the left, next to Olga. Alexander was was 26 and Aspasia was 23. This scandal led to King Alexander having to flee to Paris. He returned but not long after he died of bites from an altercation in the garden with his two pet monkeys. He was 27. (Not making this up!) Alexander died in October 1920 and his grandmother, Olga, served as Regent of Greece until her son Constantine could return from exile in Switzerland to be king for a second time. He abdicated for the second time, in 1922. Prince Christopher married a wealthy American widow in early 1920. He was later to become an uncle of the current Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olga_Konstantinovna_of_Russia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constantine_I_of_Greece en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophia_of_Prussia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Greece en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Aspasia en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Christopher_of_Greece_and_De...

White mourning was considered a privelege of queens in Europe (although not generally practiced by Orthodox Queens).  White mourning was first a privilege of Queens of France.  Numerous other queens adopted the practice.  There is a famous portrait of Mary Queen of Scots in white mourning for her first husband Francis II of France.  However, black mourning was adopted by Catherine de Medici (Mary's first mother-in-law) upon the death of her husband Henri II, and she wore it for the rest of her life.  Black mourning then increasingly became the norm for Queens.  When Marie Antoinette was taken to be executed she was instructed by her jailers not to wear black mourning, and was provided with a white dress and mob cap.  Ironically it seems they didn't realize they were unwittingly giving her the privilege of white mourning which was reserved for Queens.

Queen Elizabeth the Queeen Mother, while Queen Consort to George VI caused a sensation during a state visit to France in which she wore all white during her entire visit.  Her mother the Countess of Strathmore and Kinghorn had recently died, and in order not to cast a pall on the state visit with black clothing, the Queen decided to adopt white mourning for her mother.  Even more recently the Duch Royal family adopted white mourning upon the death of former Queen Juliana.

"Mona" was owned by the Marquis of Anglesey, and was one of two English speedboats in the races held on Huntington Bay, Long Island, in August, 1912. The other English boat, "Maple Leaf IV", won the (Harmsworth) Trophy. It was piloted by pioneer aviator T.O.M. Sopwith. The race was the main subject of the second chapter of the book "Speedboat Kings : 25 Years of International Speedboating" by J. Lee Barrett [Detroit : Arnold-Powers, Inc., 1939], which can be found online here. Multiple articles about the event from The New York Times archive can also be found with a Google search on "Harmsworth Trophy 1912".

This lady is supporting the Democratic party ticket of Woodrow Wilson (for President) and Thomas Marshall (for Vice President). Article on the exciting election of 1912: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election...

Must be Florence Jaffray Hurst Harriman (1870-1967), wife of banker J. Borden Harriman (d. 1914). Mrs. Harriman was a major Wilson supporter, first president of the Women's National Wilson and Marshall Organization (named on the banner shown). She also cofounded NYC's Colony Club, served on the US Commission on Industrial Relations, directed the Women's Motor Corps in France during WWI, participated in the Versailles Peace Conference, and was the US Ambassador to Norway (1937-1940). She said, "“I think nobody can deny that I have always had through sheer luck. . . a box seat at the America of my times.” en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Jaffray_Harriman
Wilson , Marshal has his Vice President, was elected President in 1912 and re-elected in 1916. He was a supporter of woman's suffrage and played a key role in the passage of the 19th amendment.
Since Woodrow Wilson was a supporter of the woman's right to vote, many women supported his election.
NIckname - Daisy Harriman - was in Norway when Nazi's invaded, 1940 - escaped bombing and later returned to rescue Americans there.  Noted for bravery due to her actions.

This and a few other photographs are from the notification ceremony for President William Howard Taft at the White House on August 1, 1912. Taft was officially notified of the Republican Party's decision to nominate him as the candidate for President in the upcoming election. The actual nomination process occurred earlier in July. The mustached man to the left of Taft is Charles E. Hatfield of Massachusetts (died 1938). The bowtie goatee man to the right of Taft is publisher Luther Albertus Brewer of Iowa (1858-1933). In the tradition of that era, Wilson did not attend the Convention (which was held in Baltimore), but waited coyly at New Jersey's "Little White House" -- the summertime governor's mansion -- for delegations from the convention to "notify" him of the nomination. They no doubt caught him by complete surprise.

These boys were spectators at a Democratic political rally in Union Square, New York City, on August 20, 1912. The rally was conducted by feminists and women's rights advocates who were supporters of the Democratic candidates for President and Vice President of the United States: Woodrow Wilson and Thomas R. Marshall. At one point in her presentation, Mrs. Daisy Harriman began tossing pinback campaign buttons into the crowd of young men, who surged forward, avid for souvenirs. Notice how several of them are holding their hats upside down, hoping to catch fragments of Mrs. Harriman's largesse. The upshot was that police had to be called in to calm the crowd.

Mr. Clark was politician, and unsuccessful candidate for Democratic nomination for President in 1912, losing to Woodrow Wilson. He was accused of being part of the corrupt machine politics of the age. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Champ_Clark Clark actually had the majority of the votes for the nomination, but did not get 2/3, which opened the door to Wilson. He looks pretty confident here though. Below is article about wild and woolly 3-way election of 1912. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Election_of_1912

Champ Clark is shown here at Sea Girt, New Jersey, bitterly disappointed and humiliated after the 1912 Democratic National Convention, in which he lost the party's Presidential nomination to Woodrow Wilson. Sea Girt, a resort town, was the location of the New Jersey "summer White House." Wilson, who was still the Governor of New Jersey, received visitors there while he mapped out the fall campaign. Clark was part of a delegation of Congressmen who came to Sea Girt to congratulate Wilson.

We work with glass negatives occasionally at my work.  It never fails to utterly amaze me that something so old can make such a fine image to this day.  And that in turn always leads me to wonder about the permanence of the images we are making today.  This is amazing.

See the Naval Historical Center page on Alabama. In particular, this image (#NH 57753) shows the same ship viewed from the port side at, apparently, the same event--note the number 9 on the banner and the canopy and large US flag at the rear. The caption on that photo says: "Off New York City, during the October 1912 Naval Review." That sounds like the date for this series of photos, perhaps. Why the number 9? Perhaps it is misidentified, but if so, it would seem the photo at the Naval Historical Center is as well. Note that this photo (linked from this page) shows Michigan (BB-27) at the October 1912 review in New York, and Michigan has a banner with the number 17. (So the banner does not appear to correspond to the ship's designation.) Perhaps the banner was some particular number for the event, keyed to a program or something like that? Note added: The Wikipedia article on Naval Review gives details of the event: "14 October 1912, North River, ships including USS Delaware (BB-28) and USS E-1 (SS-24) passed before the President (Taft) and the Secretary of the Navy George von L. Meyer." The date is also given as 14 October 1912 in this article from the New York Times, February 19, 1914.
This list: www.geocities.com/scs028a/1912List.html suggests that both vessels were present at the review.

The 1910 date listed for the Bain photo at the top of this webpage is incorrect and should be labeled 1913. If you search the Bain collection for "saratoga race track, " you get two citations only: Records containing the exact phrase: race track saratoga. 1. Horse racing - race track, Saratoga, July 1913 1913. 1 photographic print LOT 11146-7 LC-USZ62-120652(b&w film copy neg.) 2. Race track - Saratoga [no date recorded on caption card] 1 negative. Bain News Service, publisher. LC-B2- 2438-9 LC-DIG-ggbain-10754(digital file from original neg.) The two citations are for the same image -- which the image at the top of this Flickr page. Look closely at the people in the foreground to see that the two photos cited are identical (except one looks a little darker than the other). Thus, both photos have to be from July 1913 as in citation #1.

This picture can be eactly dated: September 9, 1912. Jules Vedrines - the French flyer - turns here one of the pylons in the James Gordon Bennett Cup Race held in Chicago. Vedrines flew the Deperdussin Monocoque racer (1912 model) with a Gnome 14-cylinder rotary engine rated at 140 - 160 hp. Competition was minimal, only two other machine were flying (a Hanriot monoplane) flown by Andre Frey and another Deperdussin monoplane (with a lower powered engine) was flown by Prévost. Prévost finished and became second, Frey got engine trouble and did not reach the finish. Vedrines beat during the race the world speed record, setting the world speed record for 20 km (12.4 miles) covering the distance in 6 min. 56 sec. at a speed of 107 mph. Source: Reed Kinert. Racing planes and air races. Volume 1

Flora Whitney was later engaged to Quentin Roosevelt, the son of President Theodore Roosevelt. Both Quentin Roosevelt and Tommy Hitchcock Jr. became fighter pilots in World War I and were shot down by the Germans. Quentin Roosevelt was killed, Hitchcock was captured but escaped. Hitchcock also ended up getting killed flying a fighter plane decades later when he was the Army Air Force attache to the US Embassy in London during World War II when he was test-flying a P-51 Mustang, the development of which he was heavily involved in.

Ebenezer "Indian" Allan built the area's first grist (flour) mill just north of the Genesee River's High Falls. : www.visitrochester.com/static/index.cfm?contentID=16 "Indian Allan," who was given a 100-acre plot of land on the west bank of the Genesee, if he built a mill for the use of the Indians -- was he scalawag as some claimed or were his descendents tricked out of the land that one day would be the future city of Rochester?: search.barnesandnoble.com/Rochester/Blake-McKelvey/e/9781... That is Sydney Edward GREGORY, Captain of the Australian cricket team in 1912. He is wearing the "baggy green cap" which is part of the uniform of our cricket team to this day. The Australian Coat of Arms with kangaroo and emu can be distinguished on the front of the cap in this picture. Born 14 April 1970, Died 1 August 1929. Right-hand bat, Right-arm bowler. Test batting average: 24.53 runs. See portrait photo here: content-www.cricinfo.com/ci/content/player/5438.html

Sydney Gregory made his first debut in New South Wales in the season of 1889-1890. He was then later selected to tour England with the Australian team. He was an amazing cricketer! He is one of only three test cricketers to have batted in every position of the batting order, from one to eleven, in his test career. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syd_Gregory

From www.genevany.org/50/ '1912 Cyclone hit SW edge of Geneva on September 1; razed huge barns on White Springs Farm. ' And from www.belhurstcastle.com/whitehistory.html 'Sunday, September 1, 1912, was a day of disaster for White Springs Farm and the immediate vicinity. A cyclone wrought havoc, leveling the main group of dairy barns and uprooting most of the beautiful elms on the farm. A three-quarter ton dinner bell from one of the barns was found a half-mile away. Miraculously, there was no loss of human life, though four or five calves were killed. Clean-up operations were extensive, and tree experts were brought in to salvage what trees could be saved. Mr. Lewis sold the Guernseys, rather than replace the barns. By 1920 the cattle business was over.' Since then, the farm has apparently been a poultry farm, an orchard, a home for the elderly, and is now a hotel and winery.

The WE Scripps of Detroit, may be: William E. Scripps scrippsmansion.com/ the following is from the above link: Scripps also loved boating and designed a successful and powerful marine engine which was manufactured until the middle 1950s. He sponsored the William E. Scripps Trophy and was part of the group of prominent Detroiters who successfully brought the now famous annual Gold Cup boating race to Detroit. Book by Thomas Fleming Day "The Voyage of Detroit" www.amazon.com/Voyage-Detroit-Thomas-Fleming-Day/dp/08844... From the Amazon description: Book Description In 1912 Thomas Fleming Day, editor of The Rudder, decided to demonstrate the reliability of the internal combustion engine by taking a 35-foot double-ended powerboat from New York to St. Petersburg, Russia. The trip was an adventure: the vessel's freeboard was only 21/2 feet so she was usually awash and always rolling; the engine noise was deafening; and the boat caught fire and nearly blew up. After completing the rugged North Sea leg, Day writes, "...The last thing I did was to visit the engine room and kiss the motor good-bye..." It would be interesting of course to be able to identify the people in the photograph. From the Scripps site there is mention of Scripps having a children. It would be possible that could be him in the suit, and maybe his child christening the ship. - just a guess though

More on the skipper: From www.bermudarace.com/TheRace/BermudaRaceRollofHonour/tabid... "An English-born American, the visionary Thomas Fleming Day founded the Bermuda Race in 1906 with the revolutionary aim of providing an ocean race for amateur sailors in normal boats. Until then, entries in ocean races were larger than 100 feet and sailed by professional crews. “The danger of the sea for generations has been preached by the ignorant,” Day proclaimed. Amateur seafaring, he said, is a healthy thing to do. “A noble art makes noble men, and there is no nobler art than seamanship.” Besides building character, Day knew that an ocean race would improve the breed of sailboats by testing them on the open sea. He arranged with the Brooklyn Yacht Club to start it the race in New York Bay, and with the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club to finish it off St. David’s Light. Besides establishing a mission for the race, Day skippered the first winner." He also edited a magazine called "The Cruiser" and wrote several books on sailing.

Their 104-foot flying ship, finished almost to the last details, is at Kane's Amphitheatre, at Clason Point, awaiting a trial trip, which the inventors intend to make soon, probably to Governors Island. Hard to tell with his hand in front of his face, but I think that's Woodrow Wilson second from the left in the front row!

The tradition was that Wilson did not go to the convention, but waited at home, and after a candidate was chosen at the party convention, a delegation went to "notify" the candidate that  he has been selected.  (As if he had not been campaigning for it the whole time!).  This notification ritual was just about done at this point, an artifact of earlier times.

Alas, an artifact that is missed. No constant campaigning for two years, no endless fundraising, no endless straw polls, beginning as early as a year before the first primary; just some back room deals for a few weeks and you're the nominee. 

I'm not sure that we've gotten better candidates since then, just a far more convoluted process that doesn't have much to do with governing.

New Jersey Governor Woodrow Wilson, the Democratic nominee, received this delegation at the Governor's summer residence in Sea Girt, New Jersey, on August 7, 1912. This link takes you to a photo of the delegation with Wilson, and even a recording of a portion of Wilson's speech on that occasion: www.woodrowwilsonhouse.org/index.asp?section=timeline&...

New Jersey Governor Woodrow Wilson meets with one of the delegations of Democratic Party officials who traveled to Sea Girt, New Jersey, to notify him of his nomination:

1)The awning where I've added a note in the photo appears to say Knox's Hats. According to this blog entry, Arnold Hatters aka Knox Hats started out in Times Square. There's a 2005 New York Times story included. So perhaps this photo is from the times Times Square area way back when -- where Broadway and 7th Avenue intersect.. 2)The lettering on the building (see another note in the photo) refers to the Garfield National Bank. According to an historic New York Times article, this bank was favored by Tammany Hall politicians. So again it appears that this photo is from Manhattan.

Looking at the hi-res version of this pic on the LOC site, there's a whole lot of text otherwise invisible on the Flickr photo. The cars have what appear to be signs with the last names of athletes--including Dukes, Donohue, Forhsaw, Erickson, Grumpelt, Gillis, Hellawell, Hebner, Hammond, Breed, Bowman, Rayner, Kiviat, and Kramer. (I've put notes on the photo detailing the barely-visible text.) Also, while it's a little blurry, there's a sign that appears to say "W 24 ST," which would make this NYC's Madison Square Park and environs. Maybe this was taken from the Flatiron Building?
Oh yeah. That building on the left has to be 200 Fifth Avenue a.k.a. the International Toy Center Building. So this is definitely around Madison Square Park.

Alice C: Thanks for the information! I am not sure if  the images at  wikipedia confirm that this is Loreley Rock, as they are taken from a different angle. We will leave source data as is for now, but let us know if you find any more photos that confirm the location.

This is certainly not Baden-Baden as the Upper Rhine Valley is wide and flat, and the Vosges and Black Forest are set back from the riverbanks by a couple of miles. The scenery is very reminiscent of the Rhine Gorge between Bingen and Koblenz: the valley is very narrow and the rail line is right up on the left bank. There are a number of cliffs and bends in the gorge, so I'm not certain that it is the Loreley, but the tags should probably read "Koblenz", "Rhine Gorge", "Middle Rhine Valley" and "Rhineland-Palatinate" rather than the last four.

NYTimes has good article on its website dated 7/29/08 talking about how Taft is notified in Cincinnati of his nomination for President by the Republican Party. Notification Day was made a holiday in Cincinnati. The Notification Committee was led by Sen William Warner of MO. The Committee was escorted from the Hotel Sinton to the Taft residence by 600 veterans of the Civil War. The Committee was comprised of Republican representatives of ALL of the states and the territories. The Taft residence was designed by Benjamin Latrobe, first architect of Washington D.C., and purchased by Taft's father-in-law. The Republican Convention was held in Chicago.
Great stuff! Taft is Notified -- Here's a link to that New York Times article, which is available as a PDF file.

But the above photo was taken at the White House in Washington, D. C., in June, 1912, when Taft was the incumbent President. This was his second experience of the notification ritual. The committee had traveled from the Republican National Convention in Chicago {yes, Chicago again} where Taft had been nominated for a second term. In the era before a candidate attended the convention in person, this was his ceremonial acceptance.

But of course, Taft went down to defeat in November. Woodrow Wilson, the Democratic candidate, was victorious, and Theodore Roosevelt, leader of the Bull Moose Party, came in second.

In the Bain Company files at LOC is a photo of Taft's 1908 notification, in Cincinnati (his home town) -- but LOC has not yet posted that photo on Flickr.
I believe the man to the right of Taft (Taft's left) is Luther A. Brewer of Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
It does appear to be Brewer--thanks for identifying him! We'll add to the description when we update.

I grew up in Geneva Switzerland in the 1960's and we always had a week off in October: "Les Vacances de Patates" left over from the days when everyone had to take off school to pick potatoes.  I just checked online and it looks like that's still being done!  I only had one classmate who had to go pick potatoes at his grandmother's farm during my entire school years, the rest of us just enjoyed our break.  This brought back memories!
Wow, absolutely vivid photographs!

Amazing photo - I picked potatoes as a high school freshman in Madawaska Maine in 1975.  School started in Madawaska in mid-August and then adjourned for two weeks in September for the potato harvest.  All the kids picked and made some extra money.  It is hard work but not onerous; the tractor goes along the rows and turns over the potato plants, exposing the potatoes, and the pickers come behind with their baskets and gather the potatoes.  Great photos to have available!

this 'human interest' is really 'awesome'  during the world war ll eras, you can survive eating potatoes in the whole year, wthout rice. potato a native of pacific  slopes of s. america, in 16th c., with roundish or oval starch containing tubers used for food. batata or sweet potato, is widely known in the philippine island, brought to table and used for food. biggest plantation of potato in the philippines is in northern luzon.

I grew up in southern Minnesota in the 50s. I was probably 5-6 yrs. old. In the fall after the potato fields had been harvested, they allowed people to come in and collect the potatoes that the machines had missed. I can still remember the cold cloudy day, playing with my brothers in the furrows of the field, throwing clods of dirt at each other, instead of picking up potatoes, and getting yelled at by my Mom.

I feel so fortunate to have been born and raised in the potato fields of Caribou, Maine.  What a wonderful opportunity to learn a good work ethic and earn money for clothes for school.  We were never cold and were well dressed at the same time.  My dad was the digger and the overseer of the whole operation...he would have to get off of the bus to life some of the children into the bus.  Sometimes he would let the men run over a barrel to build a fire to warm up our toes and fingers while waiting for the hard frost to melt on the ground so that he could dig and we could pick!!  Betty Bubar Collins

Sweet Hard Working Boys.   In those Days Gone By, most Children on Farms worked hard.   Not only to pick up the Potatoes, but they had the job of hauling them to the Cold Cellar.   This Photo is Great Tribute to the Boys, from way back then.

New potatoes are simply young potatoes. The "new" implies new to this growing season and not stored from last fall. They are usually harvested in spring / early summer prior to full maturity and are small and thin skinned.  During this time period, when affordable produce was local (6lbs of Ohio potatoes, or 5 Florida grapefruits = the same price) the "new potato" was one of the few local early ripening foods available in the spring, and very much in demand.

A note on new potatoes: as jsdellinger says above, they're from the new harvest and not out of storage.  The properties of the starch in the potatoes will actually change during storage so new potatoes with their thin, delicate skins are best for boiling, old potatoes are best for baking.  When you've been eating the potatoes from last year's harvest, the first harvest of new ones is a real treat!

Think about this: those citrus fruits  must have had to be shipped for hundreds of miles to get to that market. That was, and still is, no small feat. It supplied people with delicious, nutritious fruit, but now we take it for granted that oranges will be available, whether we're in California or Michigan(and It's taking a toll). It's nice to appreciate what energy has to be spent to get us those simple "necessities". Potatoes could have been grown locally, but that citrus, man, it's a world-traveler.

pejorg2000, I believe that even-numbered addresses are on the north side of the street. If they were back in Grand Grocery's day then I'm thinking the store would have either been located where the Embassy Suites or on the southeast corner of the block which is occupied by the Journal Star. I could very easily be wrong though.

Regarding roderickbodine's observation that the oranges in the center of the pile looked brown- It looks to me that those particular oranges are not brown, but are wrapped in tissue paper. For those not old enough to remember, it was for many decades the custom of fruit packers to wrap fruits individually in sheets of colored tissue paper. Sometimes the tissue was blank, but most often it contained the brand name of the fruit packer. (Here's a web page about fruit wrappers.) The practice on wrapping individual pieces of fruit faded away in the U.S. in the 1950s, but I gather that it is still done in some countries that have lower labor costs. Today, of course, fruits in American markets are branded by those little stickers that are so hard to peel off. I preferred the tissue, but it was undoubtedly more wasteful of resources.

Kodachrome uses external dye couplers that are added at the time of processing. All other color films use dye couplers integrated with the emulsion. This makes the Kodachrome process much more complicated but the image is far more stable. This slide will still look good long after we're all dead.

The reason for the fine color, undoubtedly with no restoration, has been explained.  Also consider that LC will have kept the slides in proper storage conditions, which many home slides and phots are not stored in.

Remember that this was during WWII, when a great deal of the factory and other work was done by "Rosie the Riveter" and her friends.  If you don't know that poster image, google it (or yahoo it). Women did indeed do all sorts of "factory work" and men's work that they'd never done before, as all the men were off fighting and dying.

Also consider that it is 99 percent sure that this was NOT a candid, but a posed shot of a selected woman who was told to dress more formally, wear makeup, and so forth.  

Women's Lib?  Probably not.  It was a wartime necessity, and afterwards a great many of them went back to usual "women's work" at home.  Think of June Cleaver, who, if there were any back story, may well have been riveting wings of P-38s a few years earlier, but in the 50s was cooking dinner in heels and hose.

Like ACFred above, I've also had a go at re-processing this photo, starting with the 141MB TIFF image from the Library of Congress: I'm not suggesting all these old photos should be "enhanced" until they look like they were taken yesterday, but it is interesting to have a look at them after processing nonetheless. And that being said, there's certainly room to improve the JPEG encoding of these images even without touching the colour-balance - just compare the large version of this image to the large version of mine to see the extra detail that's there. I've uploaded the full 7788x6384 pixel image there if you want a look - it's about 7MB.

I was in the Air Force for 13 years and work in a plant similar to this one. As her armband says Vega Aircraft Inspector her job may not be a dirty one.. Her job was probably to inspect newly made wire harness for the avionics systems or bomb bay systems.. Today they are called Quality Control and they rarely get dirty unless they have to crawl into a tight space somewhere on the aircraft itself.. The tool in her hand is a Pen Light used for inspecting the connectors in the wire harness and the gloves were for handling those connectors because they have notches in them for tools to grab on too.. Some of these notches can be very sharp and give you metal splinters i know because i used to get them all the time.. Here are some pics of 1930's-1940's Pen Lites: www.flashlightmuseum.com/flashlights/MI00046.jpg -and- www.flashlightmuseum.com/collectors/craig_smart2.jpg These are not live wires she is sitting at a work bench see the shelves to the left! ;=) -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=- Oh beautiful picture thanks for sharing. This photograph matches the pictures I have in my mind from stories my mom told me about the war, WWII, the big one.  There was something inherently glamorous about that era -- hard as things were -- we were united as a country -- the women were beautiful and the men were brave.  I would almost have to be dead now to have lived through that era (instead of being born in it), but sometimes, when I look at these photos and listen to the big band music reminiscent of the times, I almost would trade my life for hers.  She had a gleam in her eye when she spoke about those times.... the sacrifices were a privilege, not a burden.  This photo captures that sentiment precisely.

My mother worked in a factory during World War II and she wore her hair in something called a snood while she worked.   (Sort of a hair net) Yes, this is probably a posed shot.  Many photos like this were used to encourage women to go to work in factories, that needed workers.  A large percentage of men were fighting in the war.  Enough history ranting.  It is a great shot.
Said "makes me think of how our standards of female beauty have changed" Changed in what way? She's a beautiful woman, now or then...

This was a posed shot, yes, but don't assume that most women didn't dress this way, that she wasn't a real worker or that those aren't her real clothes. There are many candid shots of the period that show women just as well dressed; they simply had different standards of formality than we do. Not everyone who worked in a factory position wore a snood, and lots of women wore dressy snoods as a fashionable item. Considering the kind of work she is doing (inspection) her clothes, hair and makeup are quite reasonable. Most women at that time would find it unthinkable to go out without at least lipstick, unless they were working in a really grubby job. They wanted to work, not give up their femininity.
The rolls of her hair are dressed over rats. It wasn't just curled with curlers and then pinned up.

You don't just go and enter an aircraft factory with a camera and shoot. The photographer certainly had limited mobility and time to do his work, and certainly the workers were aware. Now, can you picture a woman not dressing up for a photo-shoot she knows when it will take place? Me neither. -- Seen in your 1930s-40s in Color set. (?)
this photograph is beyond perfect. the complimentary wires to her arm band, her hair and the red instrument she's got in her hand. the black hair. gorgeous. that dress!

My grandmother was a welder for North American Aviation in Southern California....an artist did a couple of pencil drawings of her working - she worked there around 1943. If you click on this picture, next to it are her pay stubs and her termination letter....when the boys came home, they wanted their jobs back!

A true pioneer representative of all those extraordinary (and mostly forgotten) American women who helped win the great war, and eventually transformed the social world !! What an inspiring and delightful photo.
Extraordinary

Of course it is propaganda - it's a rather glamorized war worker. What I strongly disagree is your tell tale. The lighting looks crude even for the time. Photographers have despised harsh lighting since they abandoned the pinhole. The light comes from slightly camera right up, not softened at all. It's the basic portable on-camera flash of photojournalism of the time. What may give you the impression that it looks good is that Mr. Jack Delano managed to get a good angle on her head so the light looks a little bit more natural. -- Seen in my recent comments. (?)

To get rid of rectangles on the photo Just click on All Sizes Link with magnifying glass above the photo in upper left.The larger photo will help to see what she is holding in her hand better also. Also as this description says,the woman is Shown checking electrical assemblies which you can see clearly that what she is holding in her hand is a testing probe with small metal tip at end of it and alot of plastic around it so nobody gets shocked from electricity. Everything was larger back then but if you have ever seen a digital meter for testing today,you will see plastic handles with small metal tip at end and a wire coming out of the probe and goes into the meter. Either the wire or cable on the probe in this photo is hiding or it could have just a small light on end to tell if there is any current . Either way there is nothing fake about the photo,besides a nice looking woman that most likely dolled up beforehand because she knew she was going to be photographed. My mom worked in factories, standing on her feet for 8 or 9 long hours, in a dairy packing ice cream until her hands gnarled and cramped from cold, in dry cleaners where the temperature reached 120 and the fumes quite possibly contributed to her Parkinson's Disease, and doing every other kind of labor imaginable, she wouldn't dream of leaving the house without her "face" on, and the same held true for my friends' moms. Only women who have always HAD a choice would assume that doing "men's work" was a right, a privilege or a political posture - for my mom and my friends' moms, it was an inescapable, bitterly accepted necessity. June Cleaver (and all her real-world sisters) had it pretty darned good, if you stood in my mom's shoes.

Rosie the riveter

When you look at enough pictures of wartime workers you see two kinds of photos.  One kind is posed for publicity/propaganda purposes; the workers (both men and women) spruce themselves up to look their best.  After all, they're going to be in the papers or a magazine, where friends and family will see them, and they took pride in their appearance.  The other kind are documentary pictures of the actual work.  That's where you'll see Rosie the Riveter wearing safety goggles and a hair net.

Both types of photos used real workers.

The USMC has always done the best with uniforms in my opinion, especially in regards to honoring tradition. The Navy is pretty good at it too, while the Army and Air Force seem to have gone in different directions. Pretty much everything the Air Force wears is blue, with blue accents, and then some more blue on it. The Army did the same with green, but now the "Class A" and "Class B" dress uniforms have been redesigned. They went for a blue and grey "Union Army" Civil War look rather than a WWII khaki design though. = /

NiMA- If I recall correctly, the Base Commander (Station Commander, Ship's Captain or equivelent) would make this call.  Local climate is usually a prime consideration when prescribing winter or summer uniforms.  I can't recall for sure if CMC would set an ultimate date for the seasonal changeover.

The trouser crease on the left leg seems unusually conspicuous in this photo.  It does not appear to be doubled, but looks to be much wider than what I am accustomed to seeing on a USMC uniform.  It could be just the lighting.  And regarding the neck tie, although the cleft near the top, just under the knot, may give a stylish appearance, in the strictest sense, it was not prescribed during the time of my service, 1986 - 1990.
The uniform is called "Service Alphas" it's not seasonal at all. It's generally only worn when reporting to a new unit.

Although there may be only one version worn by today's Marines, those who served 20 years ago were required to maintain two sets of alphas- wool and poly/cotton.  We would unofficially refer to the wool alphas as winter, and the poly alphas as summer, although they were usually prescribed with consideration to environmental temperature  However, for inspection purposes, either style would be designated, at any time. Generally, the poly alphas got a lot more wear than the wool alphas.   Yes, alphas, as well as charlies,  were worn when first reporting in to a unit.   Alphas were also worn for ceremonies such as change of command and annual USMC birthday formations, as well as for formal events such as organized banquets.  I was addressing NiMaGaNiN's question rather than discussing any specific uniform.  Also noteworthy, the seasonal change over involving the utilility blouse specified having the sleeves rolled up for the warmer months.  Some commanders were sticklers for uniformity, which affected the wear of other items such as gloves, scarves, watch caps and field jackets.
Semper Fi

Does anyone out there know exactly what kind of shoes were worn with this uniform? Did they always match the colour of the belt? I have a uniform with a dark tan belt and wonder if the shoes would match this. These shoes look as though they are dark brown or black leather lace-ups - perhaps ankle boots or shoes? The toes are rounded i think - yes?

during my time of service, 1986 - 1990- not ankle boots.  Shoes.  Blackened leather.  Either "old school" leather with black shoe polish, or modern style Cloroframs.  Belt is khaki style, cotton ( I think), tan, with plain brass buckle and plain brass end piece.  Modernized style is anodozed gold instead of plain brass.

WW2 and prior Marines wore shell cordovan ankle-height shoes which were a dark purplish brown (used to be called "oxblood" back when it was still a common men's shoe color). 

The class A greens, BTW, were actually a field uniform at the time. The Marines posted to Greenland in '41 stepped off the gangplank in woolen greens, overcoats and camnpaign covers. They also typically wore collar pins under their scarves (ties)!

The UK had a lot of this until the Clean Air Act of 1956.  I grew up with it in Leeds (Yorkshire).  From personal work, I have seen the frequency of smog in the industrial basin of the Clyde Valley and Glasgow decrease dramatically since then. In the "old days" the hills at the other side of the Clyde were invisible for weeks on end.  During WW2 conditions became worse due to frantically  increased industrial activities for the war effort. This "reeking lum"** looks apalling today (great picture, by the way) but I tend to the view that without the USA's industrial might, we in Europe (at the very least) would have been part of the Third Reich.

** Edinburgh's nickname a century or two ago was "auld reekie" - "reek" being smoke.

Hard to believe, but redwoods bigger and older than this are still being cut down in Northern California by Pacific Lumber Company. In 1974 I personally counted the growth rings on the stump of a 54 ft. circumference giant redwood cut down in Mendocino County by Georgia-Pacific, a corporation which has since left the county after logging off all the available redwoods from its lands. There were over 1540 countable rings on the big stump I counted, plus more years of growth in the center where the wood had rotted away over the centuries. I had to use a magnifying glass to clearly see and count some of the rings. Only a tiny percentage of the original 2,000,000 acres of Coast Redwood forest remains uncut. Forest protection activists have been trying to put the brakes on corporate liquidation logging for more than 30 years. Most people assume the remaining virgin redwoods have been saved, and are amazed that some people still think it's okay to cut them down for fancy decks and wall paneling. Redwood is not used for structural lumber. It's too expensive for that, because it's so rare. There's only one place in the world where the Sequioia sempervirens grows naturally, and I'm priveleged to live there. This photo has got me started, and I'm going to find that 1974 slide documenting the 1540 year old redwood and post it in my Flickr stream soon.

One word.....

Pioneers lived inside this tree which was burned out by a lightning strike. Here, my family stands at the base of a large one Most people will never get a chance to see these. Clear cutting these 300 foot giants is a crime against humanity IMHO.
