In the early 1980s I told my class of 4th graders about a giant redwood I had seen in California that was over 2000 years old. I explained that it had started to grow before Jesus was born and the kids buzzed with comments and questions. Every once in a while someone would ask me something about the tree. Towards the end of the year, I told them some fantastic tale and one of the boys said, "yeah, yeah, we know, just like that tree in California that's older than God!"

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nwilsonphoto] The redwoods will grow nicely in Oregon too, although not to 300 feet inland near Portland. But certainly 200 to 300 feet in our coast range if they would plant them. Since they log big swaths of our coastal forests every half decade or so, maybe they should replant some areas with coast redwood, I've already seen a few sporadic spots along Hy. 26 where they planted a few giant sequoia. But coast redwood should be better. ******************** MDV Coast Redwoods

I'm surprised they don't list it in the description, but this is the Army Medal of Honor.

The item below the medal is the rosette, a six-sided pin that can be worn on civilian clothes. If I understand correctly, the ribbon shown above the medal is upside down. It should be worn with 2 stars on top, 3 below. The medal of honor is no longer pinned to the tunic, as was the case when this medal was made.

Over 45 years ago, as a brand new 2nd Lieutenant, I exchanged salutes with a Major walking down the sidewalk at Aberdeen Proving Ground. As we approached one another, I noticed a light blue ribbon with small stars on his uniform. I gave him the sharpest salute I could. I'm sure that he forgot me after five paces. I still remember that moment.

Civilized Explorer is correct, the Medal of Honor ribbon is to be worn with the two stars above and three below. Additionally when the medal is worn today, it is usually worn on the blue silk ribbon with 13 stars, regardless if the recipient is wearing military dress or civilian clothing.

I remember in the '50's a guy in my tiny home town who had one of those. I was about 10, I guess, and fully in awe of him. He was a friendly dude, easy-going, and I believe he wore the rosette on special occasions--town meetings, like. He had been a tank commander in the Battle of the Bulge. I don't recall if I ever heard the story of how he won the medal. His name, I believe, was Gleason.

I knew from my father what the medal meant.

Doug Sheley:

Yes, this is indeed the U.S. Army Medal of Honor, so we can add that information to this record when we update. Thanks for the comment!
The Medal of Honor is often INCORRECTLY identified as the "Congressional". Take note that it is presented by the Commander in Chief of US military forces  and not by a senator or representative.

It isn't exactly incorrect to call it the Congressional Medal of Honor. The medal is given by the Dept. of Defense and is USUALLY presented by the President, but hasn't always been. The medal was created on July 12,1862 when President Abraham Lincoln signed S.J.R. No. 82. It read: Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, that the President of the United States be, and he is hereby, authorized to cause two thousand "medals of honor" to be prepared with suitable emblematic devices, and to direct that the same be presented, in the name of the Congress, to such non-commissioned officers and privates as shall most distinguish themselves by their gallantry in action, and other soldier-like qualities, during the present insurrection (Civil War). On March 3,1863 offficers were also allowed to win the MoH. On August 5,1958 the Congressional Medal of Honor Society was chartered by President Dwight D. Eisenhower. For more info check out their website at www.cmohs.org

Stunning quality of photograph. I recently shot an event on reversal film (Fujichrome Provia), and was able to have it processed and scanned in a few hours. As a result, my shots were on Flickr so soon, most people who saw them assumed they were shot digitally. I pointed out that while digital is now up to an extremely high standard, film has been there "for a few decades". But even I was stunned when I came across this photo from the early 1940s! Admittedly, the film would've been rather large in format and very low in sensitivity, and thus not as easy to work with, but the final quality is still astounding.

The Willow Run, Michigan location was a factory owned by Ford Motor Company, which built Consolidated B-24 'Liberators' under license. Ford's long experience with assembly line techniques meant that, according to mechanics who maintained them, the Ford-built B-24s tended to be a higher quality product than their Consolidated-built counterparts.

The yellow chromate primer seen here would have received an Olive Drab over Neutral Gray camouflage job; natural metal finish aircraft would not have carried this primer on the external surfaces.

About those engines . . . Most aircraft engines used in WWII were radials. That means there were odd numbers of cylinders in a circle. Usually 7 or 9. For heavy bombers the engine often had as many a 4 banks of cylinders stacked for totals up to 36 cylinders turning one propeller shaft. And that is only one of four engines. I once flew in a C97, which is the cargo version of the B29 bomber. The crew told me that aircraft was powered by 156 cylinders. The B24 engine is probably similar.

Hello Mr. Flikker:  Thank you for your interest in this photograph. The majority of the United States Farm Security Administration/Office of War Information (FSA/OWI) photographs depict life in the United States. OWI probably acquired this image of Paris from an outside photographic source  and added it to their files. That is probably why the FSA/OWI collection does not contain more images of this event.

Small point: there is no "roll" as such. If you look at the photo, you will see, on the right and top and bottom, thick lines. These are the shadows of the plate holder, telling us that the picture was taken with a Graflex camera, perhaps a Speed Graphic, which was the premier press camera of the 30s-50s. As well, the corners of the shot are perfectly square. Slides taken on a 35mm roll will have rounded corners from the cardboard slide mount.

With the Graflex cameras, each shot was taken separately, with the plate holder and film pushed into the camera back together. The cover was then extracted separately and the picture taken, the cover put back in, and the exposed shot (properly covered) extracted. Doesn't make for fast work, but the 4" x 5" negatives hold something like 45 megapixels of information.

The Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress is a four-engine heavy bomber aircraft developed for the United States Army Air Corps (USAAC), introduced in the 1930s. Competing against Douglas and Martin for a contract to build 200 bombers, the Boeing entry outperformed both competitors and more than met the Air Corps' expectations. Although Boeing lost the contract due to the prototype's crash, the Air Corps was so impressed with Boeing's design that they ordered 13 B-17s. The B-17 Flying Fortress went on to eventually evolve through numerous design advancements.

The B-17 was primarily employed by the United States Army Air Forces (USAAF) in the daylight precision strategic bombing campaign of World War II against German industrial, civilian, and military targets. The United States Eighth Air Force based in England and the Fifteenth Air Force based in Italy complemented the RAF Bomber Command's nighttime area bombing in Operation Pointblank, to help secure air superiority over the cities, factories and battlefields of Western Europe in preparation for Operation Overlord.[4] The B-17 also participated, to a lesser extent, in the War in the Pacific, where it conducted raids against Japanese shipping and airfields.

I'm sorry to report that this photo has been mislabeled, probably all the way back to its original publication. The women cannot be working on a Douglas C-47, because the type of engine shown was never used on the C-47. (Also its placement is wrong for a C-47 engine: it is mounted underneath the wing, while C-47s had their engines roughly centered in the wing.) Most likely they're working on a Douglas A-20 twin-engined bomber, which does match the engine and propeller type in the photo. Looking at the full resolution version available at the Library of Congress, the engine's data plate is readable enough to show that it is a R-2600 Cyclone 14 built by Wright Aeronautical. That is a bigger, more powerful engine than the Pratt & Whitney R-1830 Twin Wasp which the C-47 used. The propeller blade specification can be read as an 6353A-21, also a type not used with the C-47. (The C-47 did use the 6353A-18, but that's a longer blade.) Both the engine and blade types match the A-20, which as far as I can tell was the only aircraft to use that blade type—hence I conclude this is an A-20.

See also this photo, taken at almost the same moment:
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2179920874/]

B-25B.  The C-47 had a strut on either side of the wheel, while the B-25 had the strut inboard of the wheel.  Also, the C-47/DC-3 did not have landing gear bay doors (that dark rectangle just above the wheel)...the landing gear pivoted forward into the engine nacelle.  

The B-D model had the turbocharger intake lush with the lip of the cowling...Turbochargers on later models were located higher on the cowling and further aft.  Probably not a C/D model as they had an inflatable black rubber de-icer boot on the leading edge of the wing (look above the prop).

The Pilot is standing in front of an A-20B Havoc - The A-20B was produced by Douglas starting in late 1941 through late 1942.  The give-away is the position of the carburetor scoop - it's nearly flush with the front of the cowling. Also, the engine pictured is an Wright twin row R-2600 - note the ignition harness, the DC3/C47 used the single row R-1820 (DC3) or the single row R-1830 (C-47). And finally, it is definitely not a B-25 since the B-25 was manufactured by North American Aviation.
Armchair Aviator: Thanks for your identification of the airplane.  We will update the source data and reload the description.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/74803546@N04] Remember that this is a deliberately staged photo meant for official U.S. government wartime propaganda. But if you think this is good, try looking up the full-resolution version of the photo. The clarity goes from "good" to "amazing", and yet there's no doubt when it was made. There's the kind of photo you're used to thinking of as typical for 1942, and then there's stuff like this. This is what you could achieve if you had access to the very highest quality of camera and film materials, which the photographers on this government project did. The film used for shots like this could be several inches across, which gives you an enormous amount of film grain (think of microscopic, somewhat randomly arranged analog "pixels") to work with. Zoom in on a very high-resolution scan of an old top-quality photo like this and you'll see the analog "noise" from the film grain.

I've seen photos just as sharp done in black and white from as far back as the *Wright Brothers* (think 1903), or even earlier. Again, the key is to have a skilled photographer with a really good camera, focused well, using enormous (and expensive!) film plates as big as a small sheet of paper. For really old photos, it also helps if the subject doesn't move much; otherwise details get smeared across the image because of the long exposure time needed. There are plenty of old sharp photos with such little smeared details where something like a flag or a cloud of steam was obviously shifting around.

The other catch was that photos like this had to be processed into slide transparencies and projected to see the full detail, because they couldn't be printed with anything like this degree of clarity. If we're lucky, the film plates, negatives, or slides were kept well preserved, so that we're now able to digitize them to get images like this. Other times we're not so lucky, and the chance for good modern images has been lost.

I was wondering how agile you can be and how much leverage you can exert when working with such outstreched arms, and how much visual feedback you can get at that distance and from that perspective. That just does not appear to be an effective posture for engineering work. The male instructor supervising the work from above, appearing into view like an intervening supreme heavenly being in conjunction with the caption give the picture subtones of patronizing condescendence, not of defiant confidence and proud heroism. But thenm you see, this was the 1940s, so nobody really noticed. Maybe it even matched expectations or it was what you could dare to depict within the narrow limits of allowable - and under the circumstances of those times - necessary emancipation.

As a combat vet of WWII (Yes, I understand about the forties) perhaps I was "taking sides"; however as a working  engineer and one who worked on rockets, in some tough positions,  I think the posture not all that unrealistic. My sister worked in a "war plant" when I was in the millitary.

Warm Greetings:

After WWII, my father returned home and began cross country truck driving, later completed college schooling as an artisit, and technical illustrator. When I was still young (but old enough to remember), he'd take me to work with him on occassion at the Brooklyn Ship Yards, where my father was on government contract. I remember seeing the huge ships that were under construction there- just as awesome as the photo above.

In later years we moved to Long Island, lived a stone's throw from Grumman's air filed and aircraft manufacturers; it was a common sight to see full scale plane construction of transport, and new jet planes rolling off the assembly line. It also served as a test field. We also lived close to the active military base at Mitchell Field, between Uniondale and Garden City/ Westbury, NY-  I visited these places and it was amazing to go in the hangers and see huge engines, huge transport planes, jets, and fighter planes on the tarmac, some of which rumbled the ground and broke the sound barrier over our homes! The mechanics we met would explain how critical their jobs were, in keeping the planes in shape, and ready to take flight at a moments notice. During the war years, women played an enormous part in the war effort.

Many went on to have long careers in airline service, still using engines like this.

These are B-25's NOT A-20 Havocs.  Easy to spot difference is the tail assembly.  B-25 has a twin tail. A-20 had a single tail.  Note:  The A-20 also had the nickname: Widow Maker

"Widow Maker" was a nickname for the Martin B-26 Marauder: www.flickr.com/photos/hawk914/533638778/ When introduced the B-26 had a comparatively high accident rate. Those who flew it noted that early models had a problem with runaway propellers (constant speed props failing to flat pitch at takeoff): www.b26.com/page/shop_talk.htm

I suspect there have been several aircraft called "widow maker" over the years :)  Thankfully, my father survived the A-20 quite well :)  I do think that the term Widow Maker might have been applied to the night fighter version of the A-20, or perhaps its successor.  One was IIRC the P-60, the other the P-71 and I can never remember which was which.
What a great photo!  My grandfather was a turret gunner in one during the war.

It's clearly an image from a 4X5 camera--see the index marks at the top right, which are there so that darkroom techs can determine the film type by touch.  I'm not certain, but I believe that this is a Kodachrome transparency. The lenses of the day were certainly capable of this sort of sharpness, and the lighting was most likely done with floods; strobes hadn't been invented and flash bulbs wouldn't have been an ideal solution. This photo was more than likely staged, as part of a "photo shoot" intended to generate photographs to encourage public support for the war effort. But it was probably taken on-site, at the Douglas plant in Long beach, California.

Living during those times (I in the Pacific Theatre and my sister in a "War Plant" (as we called them - not factories - don`t know why) we didn`t get all bent out of shape about women`s rights, etc - just did the job.

Bear in mind we just started to come out of the Depression (this one in 2008 is a walk in the park so far) and besides patriotism (which was expected not an exception) many were elated merely to have a job and food on the table with decent clothing.

I don't have a garden to produce vegetables for canning, but I do can chicken stock or beef stock. Home canning is not as widespread as it used to be, but it's still common enough that my local large drugstore carries canning supplies.
Great collection!!
My mom and dad used to stay up very late at night canning food from our garden.  This was after a full days work.  They used an old pressure cooker to seal the jars.  The results were delicious.
This looks like a normal stack of preserves  from my Georgia Grand parents basement shelves in the 1950's (but they had more Peaches and watermelon)

I see turnip Greens, beans, peeled and cut up potatoes, the red things look like canned radishes, but never heard of that before? I see beets, green shelled peas, also looks like peeled bellpepper. I guess the canned everything. Its much healthier and no salt to can. If you can obtain fresh veggies and you can freeze some of them, canning is great way to go.
Mindful of the harvest from a Victory Garden I watched my mother work on in Forest Grove, OR, in 1944.
I still can my own jams and preserves.  I also do pickles and relishes occasionally. I grew up watching and helping my mom can fruits and vegetables.  My dad also canned, he did salsas and  relishes.

Bottling and/or preserving this process is called in NZ.

Mikescott, in the UK we use bottling for keeping food intact, as in these jars.  Preserving is used for jams and chutneys.  And then there's pickling, where you soak the food in brine for 3 0r 4 days and then pack it in vinegar.

The term preserving would work for all three methods, so I don't know why we split them up like this.

I learned to throw "pineapples" at Ft. Jackson, S.C. in 1966. This was not part of any propaganda effort, but as part of a training effort. When I went through basic training in 1966, we saw slides/photos like this to show us the "correct" way to do it.  You are to sight down your left arm and throw the grenade to the spot at which you are pointing. It wouldn't surprise me if even at the height of WWII, it wasn't nearly as paranoid a "Fortress Washington" as it is today.
This is now the State Department building. It was completed in the late 1930s, yet the War Department still needed to build the Pentagon to keep up with its growth and employees.

Given where the building is relative to the Potomac River, that plane could simply be on approach to National Airport, or back then even Bolling Air Force Base.  Even today, looking in that (probable) direction you would likely see planes on approach to National.  Still, that doesn't condone "Fortress Washington" :(
My mom worked here for a period of time during WWII.  She worked in the section that notified family members of soldiers deaths.
I wish it were still named the War department..  a more accurate term.

I read somewhere that The War Dept outgrew it before it was even completed, and therefore may never really occupied it. Either way, it quickly became It was instead occupied by the State Department. This entrance (only one side of a 2-block long building) was recently restored to a condition similar to that in the photo. If you ever get a chance to visit, there is an awesome mural just inside the entrance by one Kindred McLeary called "Defense of the Four Freedoms." (1941) Apparently it was covered for years by State officials who considered it too "warlike". And of course the parking lot is gone in this era of security measures. This is all off the top of my head, I wasn't expecting to come across this picture. I can poke around for info to back up my recollections..... Ref: www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/2003/09/15/focus10...

oh, and regarding the restricted air space... I am not sure, but I think that area may still be unrestricted. Airplanes fly over Foggy Bottom all the time as they come in for a landing at Reagan airport just over the river in Virginia. I don't really know how to read flight plans, etc, but I would think Arc 3 on this FAA diagram would put a plane within view of this area. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DCA_River_Visual.png

From State Magazine, May 2007, pg. 23 "The 21st Street entrance and lobby reopened January 22. Visitors entering the building are screened in the new exterior security facility. In the restored travertine and granite lobby, new turnstiles, a granite receptionist’s desk and surrounding bronze and glass security doors complement the original architecture of the grand monumental lobby. Employees and guests are greeted by the 50- foot-by-12-foot historic mural “America the Mighty,” painted by Kindred McLeary in 1942." 2001-2009.state.gov/documents/organization/84678.pdf

It should be possible to find this building, but it wasn't the headquarters of HEW in 1940 because HEW did not exist until 1953. It might have been the headquarters of the Federal Security Agency, which was the predecessor agency to HEW. The Federal Security Agency was created as an independent agency in 1939 by grouping Social Security, Office of Education, Public Health Service and other cognate programs scattered around in the Treasury, Interior, and other departments (or were independent like Social Security).

This building occupies the block between 3rd and 4th Streets, SW, and Independence Ave. and C Street, SW, Washington, DC. Currently, it houses Voice of America (since 1954) and part of Department of Health and Human Services. It was built in 1940 to house the Social Security Board and contains a fabulous set of murals by Ben Shahn in the hallways (check out www.voanews.com/english/About/upload/SHAHN_BROCHURE.pdf). The building is now named after Wilbur J. Cohen, secretary of HEW in the 1960s.

Not a P51. Perhaps an airacobra? @Rick it is a P51. An earlier variant without the bubble canopy. The version you see is probably a P-51 B/C with a Rolls Royce Merlin engine. It could also be a Mk1 (Mustang I/P-51) which went into combat on 12 May '42. The bubble cockpit was introduced later in as a solution to the "poor rearward view". A quick solution was the "bulbous" Malcolm Hood and later replaced with a teardrop canopy so widly associated with later P-51's.

It's a P51A, with the Allison V-1710 engine. The 'bump' on top of the engine is the air intake, Merlin versions had the intake under the nose rather than on top.
Allison-powered versions also had a three rather than four-blade prop and a shallower radiator scoop on the belly, but neither of those is easy to spot from this photo.

Dated as October 42  this isn't classified as P-51 for the following reason:
The production of the NA73 design for the UK had to receive the blessing of the US government before it could become ratified. A condition of the approval was the supply of two examples to the USAAC for evaluation and these two were delivered and given the designation XP-51. 
Before that however the US army had already contracted for the procurement of 150 additional aircraft for supply to Britain under Lend-Lease designating these P-51 and these differed from the earlier version by having self sealing tanks and four wing mounted 20mm cannon in place of the eight machine guns. 
From this batch 93 were supplied to Britain, becoming designated Mustang IA, 55 went to the USAAF as F-6A's, equipped with two K-24 cameras for use in the tactical recon role and the remaining two also went to the USAAF with different engines, initially as XP-78's but later brought into the family as XP-51B's.
The designation of this aircraft in US service as P-51 came after North American opened the second plant at Dallas, Texas to increase production from the already stretched Inglewood plant which did not occur until 1943 and this image is dated October 1942. In the summer of 1943 the first P-51B is produced at Inglewood and the identical P-51C is produced from the Dallas plant, operationally their first mission in USAAF service was on Dec 13 1943 when elements of the 8th undertook a long range escort to Keil from the UK

My dad told me that here in Britain, we did the same. Sawdust was spread on canals and rivers which were close to enemy targets ,so as to dull the shine on moonlit nights.(enemy aircraft would follow the river up to the munitions/aircraft factory).
Efforts would be made to make an area of wasteland/ open fields appear to be the target , using balsa wood "buildings" and using burning -oil barrels to mark a false riverbank, or false aircraft runway.
Worked, a lot of the time.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/28079146@N07] In Britain I believe they had pipe systems (called "starfish" or "Q decoys") with oil and gas decoys in empty fields near some important targets and towns. The idea was everything was blacked out, but the oil ad gas systems would be ignited and appear to be a burning target (e.g a burning factory or airfield or whatever) then the next wave of bombers would bomb the decoy which would be clearly visible and easy to aim for. See www.portsdown-tunnels.org.uk/surface_sites/qsite_p1.html and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starfish_site for details.

Yeah,jtan163 that's exactly what they did.Happened around Trafford Park, a big industrial complex near Manchester.My Dad was on firewatch there during the war.The place was surrounded by farmland and mossy bogland and they used Q decoys to good effect there, :-)

This must be how the camouflage for the Boeing production facilities in Seattle was created. An entire little (fake) city built on top of the factory area - trees, landscaping, roads, houses, and all.

I do not believe this is an image of a lead mine.  The white "spot" at the top of the mountain is "The Snowshoe" of Snowshoe Mountain.  In order to see it from this angle, this photo would have to have been taken from Willow Creek in the town of Creede itself.  The creek runs through the middle of town and the buildings don't appear to be related to mining.  I think those are simply commercial, residential, and storage buildings similar to those that abut Willow Creek in the town of Creede in the present day.

Good catch! It looks like all the photos that Andreas Feininger took in and near Creede were lumped back in the 1940s under a general assignment title related to lead mining instead of individual photo captions. Here's an interesting then&now pairing from Zyrcster, who identified another image in this series as showing Mt. Vernon Canyon Road, www.flickr.com/photos/zyrc/3344135363/ We'll update the captions for all the Creede photos now, .

Yes, this is taken at the end of Cliff Street. The big building on the right would later become part of the Creede Repertory Theatre. You can see the front of that building on their website history page about 20 years later... www.creederep.org/about/history.html

Feininger would have been standing behind this building, between it and the mountain you can see in the theatre photo.  Willow Creek runs behind this building in their photo, roughly parallel with the main street.

There were still carbon black plants operating and depositing unbelievable pollution into the air when I moved to West Texas in 1962. The prevailing winds from the west and southwest deposited tons of soot over the immediate vicinity. More than once, traffic on Highway 80 (now I-20) west of Odessa came to a stop when the black clouds rolled out over the highway on the rare occasion of no wind. The black clouds did not come out of a smokestack but billowed out of the large buildings. The man in the photo has a white powder on his face, but look at his neck and clothes. He worked in those clouds. Another danger in those plants was from hydrogen-sulfide, the odorless, invisible gas that can kill a human in a matter of seconds. It was the hydrogen-sulfide in the natural gas that was a key component of the carbon black process and the West Texas oil and natural gas wells produce massive volumes of "sour" gas. The following is the address of an article on the carbon black business in Texas: tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/doc01
Thank you Elmore Dodge for your comment and for sharing the article about the carbon black business in Texas. They provide context and improve our understanding of this image.

Somebody correct me if I'm wrong, but I think the Tulsa Mid-Continent refinery is now the Sun Oil refinery.  My graddad (I'll call him my dad since he and my grandmother Margaret raised my sister and me), Rusty Morton worked there for many years, retiring in 1982.  As a matter of fact, I'm packing up to move from my home in Blaine, WA on Puget Sound, and my granddad's Sunray DX hard hat is in there on the kitchen counter.
This is a great photo.

Mike,
The Mid-Continent Refinery in Tulsa was changed to Sun Oil Company, then Sunray DX.  It was sold a couple years ago to HollyFrontier and is still being operated.  HollyFrontier also bought the Sinclair Refinery at the same time.  They completed an underground network to move products back and forth under the interstate and community last year.  Roy Heim, Southwest Tulsa Historical Society. CrimeDet@aol.com.  Thanks for posting the picture by John Vachon.  He did some amazing photography in Tulsa and other places in the early 1940's (World War II era).

1930's and early 1940's our family lived on north main street which was just across the river from the pennsylvania shipyards. They built liberty ships during ww ii.  The shipyard workers were prominent in the 1943 race riot.

My buddies and i used to cross the railroad bridge  over te neches river and stand on the catwalks  under the rails to watch the trains go over.

In the old one room Country School the Teacher had to teach all eight grades.   There was no Kindergarten.   Sometimes there was only two precious children in the third Grade.  The Teacher back then had to teach all of them.  They were well trained .   Music Class was enjoyed by the entire School.   A Teacher back then had to be very Responsible.  Not like it is now.   Many Educators now days, can't even teach one Grade.     They complain and complain.   Look at the wages the Educators get today.   Back then the Teachers had little pay.    They even had to haul water to the School.  Outdoor toilets. Pot bellied stoves.   The Teacher even had to bring in the coal and wood.

Note the horn of Africa and the small country in northern Somalia. That's British Somaliland, which joined French Somaliland in 1960 to form Somalia. In 1991 when the civil war started, the old British Somaliland declared independence and has since maintained a stable, democratic government while the rest of the country languishes in an endless civil war. So far, no country except Ethiopia has recognized Somaliland, though there are rumors that recognition may be comming.

 Note also that Burma (Myanmar) is part of British India. This may be an old map, I think the British had seperated Burma by this time (though independence did not come until the late 1940's.) Burma had never historically been part of India and many Burmese were enraged when the British made it part of their Raj after overthrowing the monarchy in the 1880's.

dylan_rupert, the way Japanese women value white skin has little to do with Westernization.  In the past, lighter skin was seen as more attractive because darker skin was  associated with outdoor labor and thus lower class, and later cosmetic companies and the media reinforced that preference.

omelet4th:Very white skin (especially for women) has been a beauty ideal in Japan for centuries, so it was traditional to wear a very pale foundation makeup. I think it became a lot less popular in the post-war era, probably along with the influx of Western fashions generally.

So, actually, Westernization has meant _less_ white skin for Japanese women, I think (modern/Westernized sensibilities favor less makeup all around).

The clothes of course, are entirely American. Which is fitting, because so are these women. And there lies thereally shameful part of this story.

Sure, Japanese-Americans (and people who *looked* Japanese, in many cases) weren't sent to gas chambers, but I simply can't believe that these people were all smiles that they had been forcibly separated from their friends, families, homes, jobs, and businesses.

Amazing photo, but a truly horrible embarrassing context in our nation's history.

this is a beautiful photograph, and a poignant reminder of mistakes this country has made.  I feel for these women, and this photo makes the entire situation more real.  

I'm a little disturbed, however, that this would be compared to Nazi Germany - were we trying to exterminate an entire race?  Were we killing Japanese people - cooking them in ovens, or with chemical showers, starving them to death and performing medical experiments on them?  No, of course not!  

It was obviously a horribly shameful overreaction by the American government, and an error that I'm sure we all hope never to see repeated, but I think the comparison to Nazi Germany is off base.

I believe the comparisons people have made end at the fact that our government with our blessings isolated undesirable members of our society, took their property, separated them from their own families, and then placed them in camps. I'm going to make a comment that will probably be unpopular, but my intent is only to maybe bring a little more perspective into the situation. Here goes...

It's easy to judge from where we are now, but put yourself in the shoes of the average American circa 1942 when this photo was taken. On December 7th, 1941, Japan attacked Pearl Harbor. It wasn't a group of radicals or terrorists or extremists, it was Japan. The country. Specifically Japan's Navy, by order of the Emperor himself. On top of that, it was a sneak attack. Through a bungle in communication, it was not seen as a lawful and somewhat "understandable" act of war as intended, but as an evil, vicious, and unprovoked attack that KILLED about 2400 Americans in a few short moments. Over 1100 men died on in the Arizona; most drowned. They're still down there today. The American public was very angry, and very afraid. Fear is a very powerful motivator, and it makes people irrational. Just look at the "bomb scare" incident in Boston in 2007.

As someone else said above, in 1942 we weren't quite the melting pot we are today, or at the very least, the various cultures of the people of this country weren't nearly as integrated as they are now. As a result, the government reacted in the way it did, mostly out of fear, and I don't blame them for a second. I realize the absurdity of this question, but what would you have done differently? What if the decisions were up to you? What if you have reliable information that said there will be another major attack from within the country? What do you do? Wait for it to happen? How do you protect your people while not infringing upon their rights? Contrary to popular belief, the American government does not set out each day to oppress and/or ruin the lives of it's citizens, no matter what their ethnicity may be, and I'm sure that the INTENT of the interment camps was no different. The results may have strayed, but I still don't blame them. While it's true that the vast majority of Japanese Americans were completely law-abiding upstanding citizens, the FEAR that saboteurs were among them was enough to "require" the camps, and please don't forget that the general public was absolutely in support of not only the camps, but going to war itself, and of using the atomic bombs. Do not be a victim of selective memory. It's not as if there was public outrage at all of this. Nobody lined the streets in protest. No one.

While I and everyone else here NOW see that the camps were a mistake, we have the benefit of 50+ years of hindsight. Think about that for a second. 50 years before WWII, people legally kept slaves in this country. SLAVES!! Something else to think about... what happened to Americans in Japan during all of this? Were they put in camps? Or were they killed? Read about Japan's actions in WWII. Since someone remarked above about Guantanamo Bay, what happens to Americans in Iraq or Afghanistan these days? I don't know about you, but I would much rather live in a prison cell or interment camp than have my head cut off and my body burned in the streets. I'm NOT excusing the government or it's actions, I'm just trying to remind everyone to keep things in perspective.

I'm not a republican or a Bush fan in particular, but if he asked the American public in July of 2001 for its approval to deploy a few thousand soldiers to go capture a bad guy named Osama Bin Laden, everyone would have said "Absolutely not! He's all the way over there in Afghanistan! What can he do!?". If there was a proposal in 1999 to raise taxes to create a better airport security network, everyone would have said "No way! What's the point?" No one wants to do the dirty work or make sacrifices to be safe and free, they just want to be safe and free. Unfortunately, the world does not work that way. That's not America's fault.

By all means, question the government! Be a good citizen! Keep them honest! I absolutely support that! This is America, and we're SUPPOSED to do that! But don't expect them to never make a mistake. Don't expect them to be perfect. And don't judge them too harshly out of context 50 years after the fact (that goes for Japan too!). Expect them only to do the best they can with what they know, because that's all anyone can do.

romulusnr - Sorry, but not in any cases were "people who happened to just 'look' Japanese" rounded up and placed in the internment camps That simply did not happen -- That is not to say that many Asian-Americans did not face prejudice, unjustified anger and persecution from others at the time, as many people "mistook" other Asian-Americans for being Japanese- Americans, and took out their misguided urges of hatred, retaliation and revenge on these people -- And that is also not to say that it would have been justified, in any way, for them to be behaving the same way towards Japanese-Americans at the time, either... ( as, unfortunately, that also did happen ) = My own feeling in this matter is that it was on acount of "fear" that the Interment Camp order was hustled through, but it was an irrational fear, to be certain... Of course there had already been perpertrated racism against Asian-Americans, in general, long before WWII ( both on the Institutional level and also by the "general public" ) but in the case of the internment camps, that mistake arose out of the erroneous assumption that there could be no difference with "The Japanese" and "Japanese Americans" - People just couldn't seem to get it through their heads that the Japanese-Americans really wanted to be just as "American" as anyone else, that the US was now their adopted country, and that they were loyal to what was now their new homeland, and not to the government back in the "Old Country" --- A lot of this misconception did come about because of the stereotypes of Asian-Americans that were perpetrated in the popular culture of the day - ( Movies, Radio, pulp fiction, etc -) where "Oriental Villains" were sadistic, cunning and cruel, "Inscrutable" Chinese people always quoted from Confucious and said things like: "Honorable Sir" & etc - but also mainly where Asians were treated in general like some sort of otherwordly, mysterious and exotic race... And because there were simply not as many Asians living in the country at the time ( due, in great deal, to the exclusionary immigration laws that had been put in place years before, with the express purpose of severely limiting the number of Asians who could even enter the country to a bare minimum ) many average Americans throughout much of the country never even came into contact with real-live Asians, so they got their ideas about what Asians were all about from these sensationalized sources... Anyway, in the general public's mind's eye ( at the start of WWII ) A lot of people just couldn't comprehend that all the Japanese-American citizens now in our country were not all going to be rushing down into their basements, getting on their short-wave radio sets and sending secret code messages back to Japan filled with vital information for the Japanese Military -- The whole thing is stupid and absurd, of course, but I think that was the prevailing mentality at the time - ( "...Paranoia runs deep...Into your life it will creep..." ) And that is not to say, either, that their weren't those who didn't take huge unfair advantages of the situation when the Japanese-Americans were being rounded up and evacuated to the camps - Stealing property & taking businesses, and so on... Of course the smiles are all forced - they were never happy to be there, of course - it was a trial of humilation and great sorrow for them... But no, the internment camps were not Auschwitz or Dachau, either, they were not death camps, even if they were concentration camps, there was no torture going on, no gruesome and horrible medical "experiments", & no starvation or slave labor, etcetera... And there were also a prevailing attitude among many of the Japanese-Americans in the camps that they had no choice but to to "grin and bear it" - to make the best of a lousy situation, simply in order ( if nothing else ) to maintain sanity and self-respect, so they continued to have interests and keep themselves occupied, to keep up at least a "sense of normalcy" in their day-to-day lives, and to maintain a sense of community inside the confines of the camp, although of course they must have bitterly resented being ostracized from society at large - more than anything, I believe they felt deeply hurt, and betrayed by what the government had done to them... Also, yes, the Nazis did use this kind of propaganda when showing the outside world their lies about just how the Jews were being treated in their camps - in fact, they went a great deal further than this, they once set up an entire phony village-like enclave, filled it with "happy-go-lucky" Jews, and filmed their little propaganda film to show that this what was the way the Jews were being treated - like they had all been sent off to resort communities, ( "Seperate, but Equal" ) when, of course, the truth was 180 degrees in the opposite direction... I'm not sure if we really learned enough from the mistakes of the 1940's, however - witness, in the aftermath of 9/11, close to a hysteria against Americans who ethnic background was from the Near East - sporadic hate crimes, and, again, on account of "unfamiliarity" with other peoples and cultures, the lumping together of many different kinds of people from different countries and different cultures into the same bag - An obvious example being the hate-motivated attacks that came against Americans who came from the Indian Sikh tradition - their traditional turbans being confused with the kind worn by one Mr Osama Bin Ladn... I also believe many Americans came under the false impression that in all the Muslim mosques all over the country, there were plots against America being hatched, and that they were all, ( more likely than not ) in league with, and reporting to the terrorists "back home" ( in the same way people had that cock-eyed idea about the Japanese Americans doing the same back in WWII ) -- I think just maybe, if there had not been the concerted effort , previously, to bring to light the injustice and just plain wrongness of the Internment Camps of WWII, there might have been a move ( after 9/11) to start talking in terms of "rounding up" vast numbers of Americans of the Muslim faith and/or with Near-Eastern backgrounds and "evacuating" them to "Internment Camps" ? I believe we came a lot closer to a situation at least along those lines than we like to admit, in the aftermath of the horrible shock of 9/11, and in the confusion, panic and fear, no matter what Mr Bush may have been saying at the time abou thow it was not right to "single out" Muslim-Americans and Americans who had immigrated from the Near-East ...=

Missing is the fact that the Japanese culture was such that all Japanese people, no matter where they were located, were expected to be true to the Emperor and do as directed and if they did not comply, the rulers would simply assassinate family members in Japan until they complied. Basically with the brutal culture that existed at the time, all the Japanese residents in the US would eventually either have had to take action against the US as directed or suffer the loss of family members in Japan. The people were in a very difficult situation. The decision to isolate the Japanese families in the US was done for the protection of the family members.  If the people could not be contacted through the ‘messengers’ already in the US, they could not be identified as refusing the Emperor.  Many of the people in the camps understood the problem very clearly.  The recommendation to form the camps came out of the Department of the Navy, interestingly enough, and was brought to the President by a man named Fluke.  The people in camps saved untold numbers of their own family members as the lives of untold US private citizens. One of the reasons the pictures generally show happy people….because they were because they understood the reasons.  This information was published rather widely in the late 40’s after the war was over but somehow seems to have disappeared from the discussions.  Failure to isolate the people in a timely fashion would have been a travesty.

Great Lakes Steel (pictured) was in bankruptcy when it was bought by US Steel in 2003, and now known as the "Great Lakes Works". The plant is currently in operation, with many of the same employees. This photo shows a portion of the ironmaking facility, located on Zug Island. The gas holder was torn down years ago.

My dad worked at Great Lakes Steel from sometime in the 1950's to about early 1970's. He was hurt in an explosion there on Memorial Day, 1972. I have looked everywhere on the internet for info on that explosion and cannot find anything. Does anyone remember that explosion and have any info on it? Thanks.

I would drive through Questa nearly every day of the summer for 5 years when I lived in Taos.  It's still as beautiful as this when looking west.  The town has grown, not too much, a large Molly mine was built and destroyed the Red River that ran through town and down to the Rio Grande, the mine tailings were sent directly into the river.  The river has since recovered, still has a greenish blue tint, but fish are back.  Those domes are extinct volcanoes, this was once all grassland and was overgrazed by sheep which will eat grass to the root and sage and choya (cactus) moved in and have changed the landscape forever.  Not many people know this, but sheep destroyed much of the southwest due to overgrazing.
Beyond beautiful... amazing.
Ghost town or inhabited?  I thought I saw a cow or other large animal there though.  What desolate conditions to live in.

It wasn't meant to fly independently. The balloon was attached to cables, floated high aloft above a battlefield, and the attached cables stretching across the sky made it impossible for enemy aircraft to provide close air support to troops on the ground. very interesting photo, unfortunately, this is NOT an example of a Zeppelin. Since this was taken during wartime (5/1942) , it is highly unlikely that it was manufactured by the Zeppelin company in Germany. Further, the term Zeppelin, as used generically for airships, refers only to rigid airships or dirigibles. i recommend the removal of the "Zeppelin" tag for historical accuracy.

Later, Amir Faisal became king & in 1953, my father, (then) U.S.Air Force Capt. R.G. Altman spent a year in Saudi Arabia, training Saudi pilots. This is a photo of a plane that 'belly landed' on the desert. Dad is one of the men looking into the cockpit.

Wiki:
Khalid bin Abdul Aziz, King of Saudi Arabia (Arabic: خالد بن عبد العزيز آل سعود b. 1912–June 13, 1982) was King of Saudi Arabia from the assassination of King Faisal in 1975 until his own death in 1982.

Khalid was named Crown Prince in 1965, after his older brother (and only full brother) Muhammad bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud declined a place in the succession. He was not very interested in politics and gave effective control of the country to his brother Crown Prince Fahd. Khalid's preparation for ruling a modern state included his accompanying Faisal on foreign missions and representing Saudi Arabia at the United Nations. He was more liberal in terms of informing the press of the rationale behind foreign policy decisions.

I can just recall that there were stories near where i lived during the war, South of Gorham, about German spies signaling something-or-other to their associates in the Atlantic from the peak of Temple Mountain. This highly implausible tale reflects the extent to which people will make their own lives as significant as possible in times of stress and anxiety. There was no information that might have come out of the Monadnock Region that could have been of the slightest interest to our enemies, and it's extremely doubtful that light signals from Temple (elevation 2085 ft.) would be visible on the coast (roughly 65 mi. away), even on the region's rare clear nights.

The story was about lights from a Monadnock area mountain which could be seen at sea during WWI.  The popular explanation was German spies signalling U-boats, but the reality was some sort of experiment in photonics.

I know this view well, having walked up Pine Mtn many times. I remember the fire tower from childhood visits in the early 1970s. Nothing but the concrete footings of the tower remain but this vista of the Presidential Range is still unchanged

"MY VILLAGE” My lovely village “Oghaz Banda” is situated at a distance of eight kilometers north of Battagram and sixteen kilometers south of Thakot at the bottom of Kala Dhaka, a well-known mountain of Hazara Division Pakistan). It is bordered by Kotgalla to the north, enchanting Stream Nandhar and Shahrah-e-Raisham (Silk Route) to the east, Shingli Payeen to the south, Pine Forest (Nakhtaro Jungle) to the south-west and Landai - Kala Dhaka to the west. My great grandfather, Syed Pir Saadat Shah had six sons - Syed Pir Imam Shah, Syed Muhammad Issa Shah, Syed Maazuddin Shah, Syed Sirajuddin Shah, Syed Ruknuddin Shah and Syed Muhammad Ayaz Shah. First three sons, Syed Pir Imam Shah, Syed Muhammad Issa Shah and Syed Maazuddin Shah, who were from his Doadal wife, settled in Oghaz Banda and Landai, while Syed Sirajuddin Shah, Syed Ruknuddin Shah and Syed Muhammad Ayaz Shah, who were from his Turk-wife, settled in Chinar Kot, Singal Kot and Lami, etc. My village consists of four parts. The first one called “Poray Cham” which is situated to the south of the village, the second called “Barra Cham,” situated to the west and the third called “Kaar,” situated to the southwest and the fourth one called “Manzanay Kalay,” is the centre of the village. Besides, there are some colonies adjacent to my village, called Poray Shar, Kata Shar, Shagai and Khan Barai. My village has been blessed with a large number of natural springs, which have beautified it further. Well-known among them are: Chinar Cheena, Jarray Cheena, Tangwano Cheena, Khatsar Cheena, Sorro Cheena, Shar Cheena, Nakhtaro Cheena, Jabrai Cheena, Walla Cheena, Bodar Cheena and Gudar Cheena. All the people of my village use the water of these natural springs and enjoy their lives. Cheenar Spring is very popular which has a big maple tree adjacent to it. People sit under the ample shade of maple tree, drink cold water (chilled water) of the natural spring and spend their daytime in summer season. A cemented floor has been made under the shade of maple tree, which is used as “Ja-e- Namaaz” by the people of my village. Tangwano Cheena is very important and all the people take bath in this cheena (spring). We’re proud of all these natural springs of our village. There are five well-known big boulders (stones) in the surroundings of my village. These are known as Singlawano Gat, Kharro Gat, Gungay Gat, Tereh Gat and Baghrai Gutt. These boulders are the biggest ones in Battagram. We use to sit on these boulders and enjoy ourselves. We’re also very proud of having these big boulders in our village. There are three well-known small streams (tangey) in the surroundings of my village. These small streams are known as Bulbul Tangay, Tangwano Tangay and Cheenar Tangay. These small streams also fulfill the requirements of water for the agriculture of my village. Neekeh Gatta (Dady Stone) is also one of the scenic points of my village. People sit on it and enjoy themselves by viewing the beautiful natural scene of lush green fields. Unfortunately, this stone was removed at the time of construction of road to our village. People still do go to its site and enjoy themselves by breathtaking view of the surroundings grassy fields. The Pine Jungle, situated to the southwest of my village, has a great attraction. The tall pine trees, their waving leaves and branches look very beautiful. We sit under the shade of these pine trees in summer season. We also eat the fruits produced from cones (shintai) of pine trees. My village has the privilege to have such a beautiful forest of pine trees adjacent to it. My village has also the privilege of having a direct link through bridge with Shahrah-e-Raisham that connects Pakistan with China via Khanjrab Pass. This bridge is called ‘Japan Bridge’ which has been constructed over Stream Nandhar with the collaboration of government of Japan. This bridge has made my village a well-known and popular one in the whole district of Battagram. “Khat Sar” situated to the northeast of my village is also a popular scenic spot. People come to it and enjoy the eye-catching view of the beautiful natural scene of Stream Nandhar. We often take rest and spend most of our leisure time at Khat Sar. People also take picture of the beautiful scene of Stream Nandhar from Khat Sar. My village has a beautiful mosque in the centre of it. It looks very beautiful from everywhere. This mosque has a small Islamic Madrassa and a beautiful place of ablution (wazo khana) adjacent to it. Our village “Hujra” is situated to the east of the mosque. People pass their leisure time in this Hujra. This is also used as a combined guesthouse for the whole village. There are several meadows (Charagaah) to the west and North West of my village. People send their cattle to these meadows for grazing, which come back in the evening. Among these meadows, important ones are - Kaareen, Kuzzay Mattay, Barray Mattay and Chowgai. These are very fertile lands and people should utilize them for agricultural purposes. May God give courage to the people of my village to construct houses at these lands for themselves and make proper use of them. Amin! My village has also some well-known graveyards in the surroundings of it. These are called Landai Baba Graveyard, Jangrai Baba Graveyard, Paacha Baba Graveyard, Mulyano Baqbara and Spedaar Baba Graveyard, Khatsar Ziarat, Abai Ziarat and Haji Baba Ziarat. All our forefathers have been buried at these graveyards. People visit these graveyards to pray for their loved ones. May Almighty Allah grant His eternal peace to all of them. Amin! There are some spots of “rest” between my village and Landai. At these spots, people take rest for some time and get them-selves relaxed when they are under any stress. Among these rest spots, Proat Inzar, Damma, Ona ( ), Kharo Gut and Kandao are important ones. My village has the honour to have produced genius, educated, hospitable and hardworking people. It is matchless in education as compared to other villages of the area. My village has proud people. It has a large number of Haafiz-e-Quran, ulema, doctors, engineers, masters of Science, theology, business administration and computer, etc. They are very industrious and earn their living by the sweat of their brows. It has peace-loving people who want to enjoy cordial, peaceful, harmonious and friendly relations with all their neighbors. When the people of Kala Daka (Black Mountain) used to go to Battagram for shopping, on their way back, they used to spend their nights in the mosque of our village. They were used to feed by the people of my village. So my village was very popular for hospitality in the area. I love all these places from the core of my heart. I have been born, bred and spent most of the time of my childhood at these places. When I am sleeping, I always dream of these sites. When I am alone, these places are with me. My village is more than Kashmir to me. All people love it very much. My village was set ablaze by our archrival neighbours and the people were exiled in 1948. But by the grace of Al-Mighty Allah, we came back after an exile of four years. We built it once again. But unfortunately, its 85% population was devastated by severe earthquake at 8.52 (am), Saturday, 4th Ramazanul Mubarak-1426 A.H., 8th October 2005. May Allah protect my lovely village from all future dangers. Amin! 

It's intereseting to see how wheat was left in the field in 1943 and how it's done in big rolls today in 2008

This is wheat that was cut by hand, bundled or "shocked" to be picked up later by a wagon. The load was then carried to a threshing area to remove the grain from the stock. The stock or "straw" was not thrown away, but was used for bedding livestock. It has little feed value.

The harvesting today is, of course, mechanized. The cutting and threshing is done in one operation, right in the field. The straw is discarded from the combine onto the ground, and baled later. 

The large bales that you see sitting in the fields are most likely "hay", or grasses, alfalpha, and clovers that are grown for feed.

Also, the house is based upon Jefferson's own design, and it means "little mountain" in Italian.
It's also one of the few, if only, sites in the US on the UN World Historical Site list.

From Warbird Alley www.warbirdalley.com/p51.htm History: One of the most effective, famous and beautiful fighter aircraft of WWII, the P-51 was designed to fulfill a British requirement dated April 1940. Because of the rapidly-mounting clouds of war in Europe, the UK asked North American Aircraft to design and build a new fighter in only 120 days. The NA-73X prototype was produced in record time, but did not fly until 26 October 1940. The first RAF production models, designated Mustang Mk Is, underwent rigorous testing and evaluation, and it was found that the 1,100-hp Allison engine was well suited for low-altitude tactical reconnaissance, but the engine's power decreased dramatically above an altitude of 12,000 feet, making it a poor choice for air-to-air combat or interception roles. Because of this, the RAF left its eight machine guns intact, but also fitted the Mustang with cameras. In this configuration, it served in at least 23 RAF squadrons, beginning in April 1942. The first Merlin-engine versions appeared in 1943 with the P-51B, of which 1,988 were built in Inglewood, California, and the P-51C, of which 1,750 were built in Dallas, Texas. Both new versions had strengthened fuselages and four wing-mounted 12.7-mm machine guns. Many of these new Mustangs were delivered to the UK as Mustang Mk IIIs, and others went to the USAAF as F-6Cs. More info on the site...

I'll expand on why this is a F-6A:
The production of the NA73 design for the UK had to receive the blessing of the US government before  it could become ratified. A condition of the approval was the supply of two examples to the USAAC for evaluation and these two were delivered and given the designation XP-51. Before that however the US army had already contracted for the procurement of 150 additional aircraft for supply to Britain under Lend-Lease designating these P-51 and these differed from the earlier version by having self sealing tanks and four wing mounted 20mm cannon in place of the eight machine guns. From this batch 93 were supplied to Britain, becoming designated Mustang IA, 55 went to the USAAF as F-6A's, equipped with two K-24 cameras for use in the tactical recon role and the remaining two also went to the USAAF with different engines, initially as XP-78's but later brought into the family as XP-51B's.
The designation of this aircraft in US service as P-51 came after North American opened the second plant at Dallas, Texas to increase production from the already stretched Inglewood plant which did not occur until 1943 and this image is dated October 1942. In the summer of 1943 the first  P-51B is produced at Inglewood and the identical P-51C is produced from the Dallas plant, operationally their first mission in USAAF service was on Dec 13 1943 when elements of the 8th undertook a long range escort to Keil from the UK

Would question the title of this photograph - the US supplied other aircraft for RAF use (or at least evaluation). Before the P-51, the Curtiss-Wright P40A-C Tomahawk was issued (not used in frontline combat), and the P40D-F Warhawk was issued under the name Kittyhawk. This website gives a comprehensive history.
I question the title also.  The RAF used the Douglas A-20, Catalina, even B-17s.

The RAF used the North American Mustang I, IA, and II in a tactical reconnaissance role. The RAF Mustang I was armed with 4 Browning .50 calibre and 4 Browning .30 calibre machine guns. The Mustang IA was equipped with 4 Hispano MkII 20mm cannon and the Mustang II had 4 Browning .50 calibre machine guns.

The RAF Mustang III was used in a fighter role and was equipped with 4 Browning .50 calibre machine guns.

The RAF reorganised in 1943 in preparation for the opening of the second front in Europe and used the lessons learned from its operations in North Africa with the 1st Tactical Air Force - The Desert Air Force.  A 2nd Tactical Air Force was formed during the summer of 1943 and the RAF's 2 Group from Bomber Command, which encompassed all the light  twin engined daylight bombers, were all moved under the control of Fighter Command and then into the 2nd TAF.  The bomber types moved into the TAF were North American Mitchell II, and III, Douglas Boston III, IIIA, IV and V, Lockheed Ventura I, and II,and De Havilland Mosquito FBVI.  As can been seen the majority of these types of aircraft were supplied to the RAF under the lend-lease scheme with the exception of the British Mosquito.

If you follow the trackback to the LOC original and download it, what you find is that the negative is a 4" x 5", and thus most likely shot on a Graflex press camera of some sort (you can see the film plate holder outlines on the left and top and bottom). The LOC scanners set their resolution at 1500dpi, capturing roughly 45 megapixels of information. What's amazing about that is that at 100% magnification, you are just beginning to see the film grain. Today's press photographers, using digital equipment, can't capture even half this level of detail.

North America's development and production of their NA-73 design for the UK was approved after 2 examples were supplied to the USAAC as XP-51, but before that the US army had already contracted for the procurement of 150 additional aircraft for supply to the UK under lend-lease, designating these P-51 and they differed  from the initial eight gun armament by having four wing mounted 20mm canon (as pictured) .
From this batch 93 went to the UK becoming Mustang IA 55 went to the USAAF as F-6A's and the remaining 2 were also taken on by the USAAF and re-engined as XP-51B's.
Not the first models to enter combat for the US, those were A-36A's in August 1943 (P-51 with dive brakes, bomb racks and six 0.50in) which saw service in the Middle East and in the invasion of Sicily

Was it really still being called the YB-17 in 1942?

It would be specific to the aircraft in this pic which is a Y1B-17, identifiable by the visible lack of armament, bubble blister in the nose glazing, no dorsal or ventral turrets. 
It could be a 17or 17B , the only difference is turbochargers, so I suspect this is an non turbocharged aircraft

Twelve Y1B-17 were delivered between January and August 1937, equiping the USAAC's 2nd Bombardment Group at Langley Field, Virginia. The 13th test bed model was redesignated Y1B-17A and provided with GR-1820-51 engines with General Electric turbocharger (supercharger powered by a turbine driven by exhaust gas). It flew for the first time on 29 April 1938 and subsequent testing gave proof of the superiority of the supercharged engine over normally aspirated ones and such engines were to become standard.
The YB-17's were designated B-17 by the 2nd Bombardment group at this point.
There was great political tension between the Army and the Navy at this point after the interception of the Italian liner "Rex"  which goes a long way to explaining why the USAAC had only 30 on the books when war broke out in Europe. 
The order for Y1B-17 was followed by a contract for 39 B-17B's (same as the turbocharged Y1B-17A) which were all delivered by March 1940.
The B-17C, with uprated R-1820-65 engines and an increase from 5 to 7 guns were first ordered in 1939, and the first of 38 models flew in July 1940.

Some how, this entire set just doesn't seem like it was shot in 1942.  First of all the color films available at that time just didn't record colors like these.  The color films of that period simply weren't fast enough to capture exposures like these without the heavy direct flash look that we try to avoid.  In addition, the colors would have faded, or at least shifted in 66 year old photographs.

These photos certainly don't have the famous "Kodachrome" look of photos taken in this period.
